titleStmt.title: A machine-readable version of John Marston, Parasitaster or The Fawn

publicationStmt.publisher: John Marston, 1575?-1634 (1576-1634) Parasitaster, or The Fawne, as it hath beene divers times presented at the blacke Friars, by the Children of the Queenes Maiesties Revels. Written by Iohn Marston London Printed by T. P. for W. C. 1606

sourceDesc.p: From the LION version of the 1606 Quarto, STC17484, checked against the EEBO images of the same text

Play details
The fawne. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1606. Date first performed: 1604.

encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Hercules Renaldo Nimphadoro Herod Dondolo Gonzago Dulcimel Tiberio Sir Amoroso Zuccone Zoya Garbetza Philocalia Granusso Puttotta Cupid Page Poueia Ladies Prologue joint speech

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

sp.l: Let those once know that here with malice lurk,
It is base to be too wise, in others work,
The rest, sit thus saluted:
Spectators know, you may with freest faces
Behold this Scene, for here no rude disgraces
Shall taint a public, or a private name,
This pen at viler rate doth value fame,
Than at the price of others infamy,
To purchase it: Let others dare the rope,
Your modest pleasure is our authors scope.
The hurdle and the rack to them he leaves,
That have naught left to be accompted any,
But by not being: Nor doth he hope to win
Your laud or hand, with that most common sin
Of vulgar pens, rank bawdry, that smells
Even through your masks, usque ad nauseam:
The venus of the Scene doth loath to wear
So vile, so common, so immodest clothings,
But if the nimble form of comedy,
Mere spectacle of life, and public manners
May, gracefully arrive to your pleased ears,
We boldly dare the utmost death of fears
For we do know that this most fair filled room
Is Laden with most Attic judgments, ablest spirits,
Than whom , there are none more exact, full, strong,
Yet none more soft, benign in censuring,
I know there is not one Ass in all this presence,
Not one Callumnious rascal, or base villain
Of emptiest merit, that would tax and slander
If Innocency herself should write, not one we know it .
O you are all the very breath of Phebus
In your pleased gracings all the true life blood
Of our poor author lives, you are his very graces.
Now if that any wonder why he is drawn
To such base soothings, know his play is; The Fawn,

body.stage: Dat veniam Coruis vexat censura columbas.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: See yonder is Vrbim those far appearing Spires, rise from the City, you shall conduct me no further, return to Ferrara my Dukedom, by your care in my absence shall rest constantly united, and most religiously Loyal.

sp.speaker: Re:
sp.l: My Prince and brother, let my blood and love challenge the freedom of one question,

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: You have it.

sp.speaker: Re:
sp.l: Why? in your steadier age in strength of life,
And firmest wit of time, will you break forth
Those stricter Limits of regardful state
(Which with severe distinction you still kept)
And now to unknown dangers you will give up
Yourself Ferraras Duke, and in yourself
The state; and us. O my loved brother
Honour avoids not only just defame,
But flies all means that may ill voice his name.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Busy yourself with no fears, for I shall rest most wary of our safety, only some glimpses I will give you for your satisfaction why I leave Ferrara, I have vowed to visit the Court of Urbin in some disguise as thus: my son as you can well witness with me, could I never persuade to marriage, although myself was then, an ever resolved widower, and though I proposed to him this very Lady to whom he is gone in my right to negotiate: now how his cooler blood will behave itself in this business, would I have an only testimony, other contents shall I give myself, as not to take love by attorney, or make my election out of tongues, other sufficings there are, which my regard would fain make sound to me: something of much you know, that and what else you must not know, bids you excuse this kind of my departure.

sp.speaker: Re:
sp.p: I commend all to your wisdom, and yours to the wisest.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Think not but I shall approve that more than folly which even now appears in a most ridiculous expectation: be in this assured. The bottom of gravity is nothing like the top, once more fare you well.
sp.l: And now thou Ceremonious sovereignty
Ye proud severer stateful Complements
The secret arts of Rule, I put you off;
Nor ever shall those manacles of form
Once more lock up the appetite of blood.
It is now an age of man, whilst we all strict
Have lived in awe of carriage regular
Apted unto my place, nor hath my life
Once tasted of exorbitant affects.
Wild Longings, or the Least of disranked shapes
But we must once be wild, it is ancient truth
O fortunate, whose madness falls in youth!
Well, this is text, who ever keeps his place
In servile station, is all low and base.
Shall I because some few may cry, Light, vain,
Beat down affection from desired rule
He that doth strive to please the world is a fool
To have that fellow cry. O mark him, grave,
See how austerely he doth give example,
Of repressed heat and steady life
Whilst my forced life against the stream of blood
Is lugged along, and all to keep the God
Of fools and women: Nice opinion:
Whose strict preserving makes oft great men fools
And fools of great men: no thou world know thus
There is nothing free but it is generous.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.l: How now my little more than nothing, what news is stirring.

sp.speaker: Pag:
sp.l: All the City is afire.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.l: On fire?

sp.speaker: Pag:
sp.p: With joy of the Prince Dulcimels birth day, there is show upon show, sport upon sport.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.l: What sport, what sport?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Marry sir to solemnise the Princes birth day, there is first Crackers which run into the air, and when they are at the top, like some ambitious strange heretic, keep a cracking, and a cracking, and then break, and down they come.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: A pretty crab, he would yield tart juice if he were squeezed.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.l: What sport else?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Other fireworks.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: Spirit of wine, I cannot tell how these fireworks should be good at the solemnising the birth of men or women, I am sure they are dangerous at their begetting, what more fireworks sir?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: There be squibs sir, which squibs running upon lines like some of our gaudy Gallants sir, keep a smother sir, with flishing and flashing, and in the end sir, they do sir

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.l: What sir?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Stink sir.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.l: Fore heaven, a most sweet youth.

sp.speaker: Don:
sp.l: News, news, news, news.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.l: What, in the name of prophecy?

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.l: Art thou grown wise?

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.l: Doth the Duke want no money?

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.l: Is there a maid found at twenty-four?

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.l: Speak, thou three legged Tripos, is thy ship of Fools afloat yet?

sp.speaker: Don:
sp.l: I have many things in my head to tell you.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Aye , thy head is always working, it roles, and it roles Dondolo, but it gathers no moss Dondolo.

sp.speaker: Don:
sp.p: Tibero the Duke of Ferraraes son excellently horsed, all upon Flaunders Mares, is arrived at the Court this very day, somewhat late in the night time.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.l: An excellent nuntius.

sp.speaker: Don:
sp.l: Why my Gallants, I have had a good wit.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.l: Yes troth, but now it is grown like an Almanac for the last year, past dare, the mark is out of thy mouth Dondolo.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: And what is the Princes Embassage, thou art private with the Duke, thou belongest to his close stool.

sp.speaker: Don:
sp.p: Why? every fool knows that, I know it myself man as well as the best man, he is come to solicit a marriage betwixt his Father the Duke of Ferraraes, and our Duke of Urbins daughter Dulcimell.

sp.speaker: Nympha.
sp.l: Pity of my passions, Nymphadoro shall lose one of his Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Nay, if thou hast more than one, the loss can never be grievous since it is certain he that loves many formally, never loves any violently.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: Most trusted Frappatore, is my hand, the weaker because it is divided into many fingers? no, it is the more strongly nimble. I do now love threescore and nine Ladies all of them most extremely well, but I do love the Princes most extremely best: but in very sighing sadness, I have lost all hope, and with that hope a Lady, that is most rare, most fair, most wise, most sweet, most

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Anything true but remember still this fair , this wise, this sweet, this all of excellency has in the tail of all, a Woman.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.l: Peace, the presence fills against the Prince approacheth: Mark who enters.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.l: My Brother, sir Amoroso-debilidosso.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.l: Not he.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.l: No, not he?

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.l: How is he changed?

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.l: Why, grown the very dregs of the drabs cup.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.l: O Babylon thy walls are fallen: Is he married?

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.l: Yes, yet still the Ladies common, or the common Ladies servant.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.l: How does his own Lady bear with him?

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Faith like the Roman Milo, bore with him when he was a Calf, and now caries him when he is grown an Ox.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.l: Peace the Duke is at hand.

body.stage: Enter Granuffo, Gonzago, Dulcimell, Philocalia, Loia.

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: Daughter, for that our last speech leaves the firmest print be thus advised, when young Tiberio negotiates his fathers love, hold heady guard over thy passions and still keep this full thought firm in thy reason, it is his old Fathers love the young man moves, (is it not well thought my Lord, we must bear brain, ) and when thou shalt behold, Tiberios life-full eyes and well filled veins, complexion firm, and hairs that curls with strength of lusty moisture, (I think we yet can speak, we have been eloquent) thou must shape thy thoughts to apprehend his father well in years.
sp.l: A grave wise Prince, whose beauty is his honour,
And well past life, and do not give thy thoughts
Lest liberty to shape a divers scope,
(My Lord Granuffo: pray ye note my phrase, )
So shalt thou not abuse thy younger hope.
Nor afflict us, who only joy in life,
To see thee his.

sp.speaker: Dul:
sp.l: Gracious my father fear not, I rest most duteous to your dispose.

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: Set on then, for the Music gives us notice the Prince is hard at hand.

body.stage: Tiberio with his traine with Hercules disguised.

sp.speaker: Dul:
sp.l: You are most welcome to our long desiring Father, to us you are come.

sp.speaker: Tib:
sp.l: From our long desiring Father.

sp.speaker: Dul:
sp.l: Is this your Fathers true proportion?

sp.speaker: Tib:
sp.l: No Lady, but the perfect counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Dul:
sp.l: And the best graced.

sp.speaker: Tib:
sp.l: The Painters Art could yield.

sp.speaker: Dul:
sp.l: I wonder he would send a counterfeit to move our love ,

sp.speaker: Gonz
sp.p: Hear, that is my wit, when I was eighteen old such a pretty toying wit had I, but age hath made us wise (hast not my Lord?)

sp.speaker: Tib:
sp.p: Why fairest Princes if your eye dislike that deader piece, behold me his true form and livelier image, such my Father hath been.

sp.speaker: Dul:
sp.l: My Lord, please you to scent this flower.

sp.speaker: Tib:
sp.l: It is withered Lady, the flowers scent is gone.

sp.speaker: Dul:
sp.p: This hath been such as you are, hath been sir they say in England, that a far found Friar had girt the Island round with a brass wall, if that they could have catched, Time is, but Time is past, left it still clipped with aged Neptune's arm.

sp.speaker: Tib:
sp.l: Aurora yet keeps chaste old Tithons bed.

sp.speaker: Dul:
sp.l: Yet blushes at it when she rises.

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.l: Pretty, pretty, just like my younger wit: you know it my Lord.

sp.speaker: Dul:
sp.l: But is your Fathers age thus fresh, hath yet his head so many hairs?

sp.speaker: Tib:
sp.l: More, more, by many a one.

sp.speaker: Dul:
sp.l: More say you?

sp.speaker: Tib:
sp.l: More.

sp.speaker: Dul:
sp.p: Right sir, for this hath none, is his eye so quick as this same piece makes him show?

sp.speaker: Tib:
sp.p: The courtesy of Art hath given more life to that part, than the sad cares of state would grant my father.

sp.speaker: Dul:
sp.l: This model speaks about forty.

sp.speaker: Tib:
sp.p: Then doth it somewhat flatter for our father hath seen more years, and is a little shrunk from the full strength of time.

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.l: Somewhat coldly praised.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.l: Your father hath a fair Solicitor,
And be it spoke with virgin modesty,
I would he were no elder, not that I do fly
His side for years, or other hopes of youth,
But in regard the malice of lewd tongues
Quick to deprave on possibilities,
(Almost impossibilities) will spread
Rumours, to honour dangerous.

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.l: What? whisper? I, my Lord Granuffo it were fit
To part their lips: men of discerning wit
That have read Plinie can discourse, or so,
But give me practise: well experienced age
Is the true Delphos. I am no Oracle
But yet I will prophecy: well my Lord Granuffo,
It is fit to interrupt their privacy,
Is it not my Lord, now sure thou art a man
Of a most learned silence, and one whose words
Have been most precious to me, right, I know thy heart,
It is true, thy legs discourse with right and grace,
And thy tongue is constant. Fair my Lord,
For bear all private closer conference,
What from your father comes, comes openly,
And so must speak: for you must know my age
Hath seen the beings, and the quide of things,
I know Dimensions and the termini
Of all existence: Sir I know what shapes
Appetite forms; but policy and states
Have more elected ends: your fathers suit
Is with all public grace received, and private love
Embraced, as for our daughters bent of mind
She must seem somewhat nice, it is virgins kind
To hold long Out, if yet she chance deny,
Ascribe it to her decent modesty:
We have been a philosopher and spoke,
With much applause; but now age makes us wise,
And draws our eyes to search the heart of things,
And leave vain seemings, therefore you must know,
I would be loath the gaudy shape of youth
Should one provoke, and not allowed of heat
Or hinder, or, for sir I know and so,
Therefore before us time and place affords
Free speech, else not: wise heads use but few words
In short breath, know the Court of Vrbin holds
Your presence and your embassage so dear,
That we want means once to express our heart
But with our heart: plain meaning shunneth art,
You are most welcome (Lord Granuff a trick,
A figure, note) we use no Rhetoric.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.l: Did not Tiberio call his father fool?

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.l: No, he said years had weakened his youthful quickness.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.l: He swore he was bald.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.l: No; but not thick haired.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: By this light, I will swear he said his father had the hip-gout, the strangury, the fistula in ano, and a most unabideable breath, no teeth, less eyes, great fingers, little legs, an eternal flux, and an everlasting cough of the lungs.

sp.speaker: Nim:
sp.l: Fie, fie, by this light he did not.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: By this light he should have done then: horn on him, threescore and five, to have and to hold, a Lady of fifteen. O Mizenzius a tyranny equal if not above thy torturing; thou didst bind the living and the dead bodies together, and forced them so to pine and rot, but this cruelty, binds breast to breast, not only different bodies, but if it were possible most unequal minds, together with an enforcement even scandalous to Nature. Now the Jail deliver me, an intelligencer, be good to me ye Cloisters of bondage, of whence art thou?

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Of Ferrara.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: A Ferarees what to me, camest thou in with the Prince Tiberio?

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: With the Prince Tiberio, what a that, you will not rail at me, will you?

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: Who I? I rail at one of Ferrara, a Ferazees, no? didst thou ride?

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: Hast thou worn socks?

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: Then blessed be the most happy gravel betwixt thy toes I do prophecy thy tyrannizing itch shall be honourable, and thy right worshipful soul shall appear in full presence; art thou an officer to the Princes.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.l: I am, what a that?

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.l: My cap, what officer?

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.l: Yeoman of his bottles, what to that?

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.l: My lip, thy name good yeoman of the bottles?

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.l: Faunus.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: Faunus an old Courtier, I wonder thou art in no better clothes and place Faunus?

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: I may be in better place sir, and with them of more regard if this match of our Dukes intermarriage with the heir of Vrbin proceed, the Duke of Vrbin dying, and our Lord coming in his Ladies right title to your dukedom.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: Why then shalt thou O yeoman of the bottles become a maker of Magnificoes, thou shalt beg some odd suit, and change thy old suit, pare thy beard, cleanse thy teeth, and eat Apricots, marry a rich widow, or a cracked Lady, whose case thou shalt make good. Then my Pythagorous shall thou and I make a transmigration of souls, thou shalt marry my daughter, or my wife shall be thy gracious mistress. Seventeen punks shall be thy proportion, Thou shalt beg to thy comfort of clean linen, eat no more fresh beef at supper, or have thy broth for next days porridge, but the flesh pots of Egypt shall fatten thee, and the Grasshopper shall flourish in thy summer.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: And what dost thou think of the Dukes overture of marriage?

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: What do you think?

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: May I speak boldly as at Alleppo?

sp.speaker: Nim:
sp.p: Speak till thy lungs ache, talk out thy teeth, here are none of those cankers, these mischiefs of society, intelligencers, or informers, that will cast rumour into the teeth of some Lalius Baldus, a man cruelly eloquent and bloodily learned, no, what sayst thou Faunus?

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: With an undoubted breast thus I may speak boldly,

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: By this night I will speak broadly first and thou wilt man, our Duke of Urbin is a man very happily mad, for he thinks himself right perfectly wise, and most demonstratively learned; nay more.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: No more, I will on, methinks the young Lord our Prince of Ferrara so bounteously adorned with all, of grace, feature and best shaped proportion, fair use of speech, full opportunity, and that which makes the sympathy of all equality, of heat, of years, of blood, me thinks these Lodestones should attract the metal of the young Princes rather to the son than to the noisome, cold, and most weak side of his half rotten father.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Thou art ours, thou art ours, now dare we speak as boldly as if Adam had not fallen, and made us all slaves, hark ye, the Duke is an arrant doting Ass, an Ass, and in the knowledge of my very sense, will turn a foolish animal, for his son will prove like one of Balles priests, have all the flesh presented to the Idol his father, but he in the night will seed of it, will devour it, he will yeoman of the bottles, he will.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Now gentlemen, I am sure the lust of speech hath equally drenched us all, know I am no servant to this Prince Tiberio.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: Not?

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Not, but one to him out of some private urging most vowed, one that pursues him but for opportunity of false satisfaction, now if ye can prefer my service to him, I shall rest yours wholly.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: Just in the devils mouth, thou shalt have place, Fawn thou shalt, behold this generous Nymphadoro a gallant of a clean boot, straight back, and head of a most hopeful expectation, he is a servant of fair Dulcimels her very creature borne to the Princes sole adoration, a man so spent in time to her, that pity (if no more of grace) must follow him second, when we have gained the room, served his suite Hercules, I will be your intelligencer.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Our very heart, and if need be works to most desperate ends.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: Well urged.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Words fit acquaintance, but full actions friends.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: Thou shalt not want Faunus.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: You promise well.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: Be thou but firm, that old doting iniquity of age, that only eyed lecherous Duke thy Lord shall be baffled to extremest derision, his son prove his fool fathers own issue.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: And we, and thou with us blessed and enriched past that misery of possible contempt, and above the hopes of greatest conjectures.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Nay as for wealth vilia miretur vulgus. I know by his physiognomy, for wealth he is of my addiction, and bids a sico for it.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: Why thou art but a younger brother, but poor Baldazozo.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: Faith to speak truth, my means are written in the book of fate, as yet unknown, and yet I am at my fool, and my hunting gelding, come, Viah, to this feastful entertainment.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.l: I never knew till now, how old I was,
By him by whom we are, I think a Prince
Whose tender sufferance never felt a gust
Of bolder breathings, but still lived gently fanned
With the soft gales of his own flatterers lips
Shall never know his own complexion.
Dear sleep and lust I thank you, but for you,
Mortal till now, I scarce had known myself
Thou grateful poison, sleek mischief Flattery
Thou dreamful slumber (that doth fall on kings
As soft and soon as their first holy oil, )
Be thou forever damned I now repent
Severe indictions to some sharpe stiles,
Freeness, so it grow not to licentiousness
Is grateful to just states. Most spotless kingdom,
And men o happy borne under good stars,
Where what is honest, you may freely think,
Speak what you think, and write what you do speak,
Not bound to servile soothings. But since our rank
Hath ever been afflicted with these flies
(That blow corruption on the sweetest virtues)
I will revenge us all upon you all
With the same stratagem, we still are caught,
Flattery itself, and sure all knows the sharpness
Of reprehensive language is even blunted
To full contempt, since vice is now termed fashion
And most are grown to ill even with defence,
I vow to waste this most prodigious heat
That falls into my age, like scorching flames
In depth of numbed December, in flattering all
In all of their extremest viciousness,
Till in their own loved race they fall most lame,
And meet full butte, the close of Vices shame.

body.stage: Herod and Nymphadoro with napkins in their hands, followed by Pages with stooles and meat:

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Come Sir, a stool boy, these Court Feasts are to us Servitors Court Fasts, such scambling, such shift for to eat, and where to eat, here a Squire of low degree hath got the carcass of a Plover, there Pages of the Chamber divide the spoils of a tattered Pheasant, here the Sewer has friended a Country Gentleman with a sweet green goose, and there a young fellow that late has bought his office, has caught a Woodcock by the nose, flowing

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: But is not Faunus preferred with a right hand?

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Did you ever see a fellow so spurted up in a moment, he has got the right care of the Duke, the Prince, Princess, most of the Lords, but all the Ladies, why he is become their only Minion, Usher, and Supporter.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: He hath gotten more loved reputation of virtue, of learning, of all graces, in one hour, than all your snarling reformers have in ---

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Nay, that is unquestionable, and indeed what a fruitless labour, what a filling of Dams tub, is it become to inveigh against folly, community takes away the sense, and example the shame: no, praise me these fellows, hang on their chariot wheel, and mount with them whom fortune heaves, nay drives: A stoical sower virtue seldom thrives. Oppose such fortune, and then bursts with those are pitied.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: Behold that thing of most fortunate, most prosperous, Don Faunus himself .

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Blessed and long lasting be thy carnation ribbon; O man of more than wit, much more than virtue, of fortune, will it eat any of a young spring salad?

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: where did the herbs grow my gallant, where did they grow?

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: Hard by in the City here.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: No, I will none, I will eat no City herbs, no City roots, for here in the City a man shall have his excrements in his teeth again within four and twenty hours, I love no City salads: has it any Canary?

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: How the poor snail wriggles with this sudden warmth.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: Here Faunus a health as deep as a female.

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: Fore Jove we must be more endeared.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: How dost thou feel thyself now Fawn

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: Very womanly with my fingers, I protest I think I shall love you, are you married? I am truly taken with your virtues, are you married?

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: Why I like you well for it.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: No troth Fawn, I am not married.

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: Why I like you better for it; before heaven I must love you;

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: Why Fawn, why?

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: Fore heaven you are blessed with three rare graces, fine linen, clean linings, a sanguine complexion, and I am sure, an excellent wit, for you are a Gentleman borne.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: Thank thee sweet Fawn, but why is clean linen such a grace, I prithee.

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: O my excellent, and inward dearly approved friend, What is your name sir? clean linen is the first our life craves, and the last our death enjoys.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: But what hope rests for Nymphadoro, thou art now within the buttons of the Prince: shall the Duke his Father marry the Lady?

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: It is to be hoped, not.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: That is some relief as long as there is hope.

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: But sure sir it is almost undoubted the Lady will carry him.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: O pestilent air, is there no plot so cunning, no surmise so false, no way of avoidance?

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: Hast thou any pity, either of his passion, or the Ladies years, a Gentleman in the summer and hunting season of his youth, the Lady met in the same warmeth, were it not to be wept that such a sapless chafing-dish using old dotard as the Duke of Ferrara with his withered hand, should pluck such a bud, such a: O the life of sense!

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: Thou art now a perfect Courtier of just fashion, good grace, canst not relieve us?

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: Have ye any money?

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: Pish Fawn, we are young Gallants.

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: The liker to have no money. But my young Gallants to speak like myself, I must hug your humour. Why look you there is fate, destiny, constellations, and Planets, (which though they are under nature, yet they are above women, ) who hath read the Book of chance? no, cherish your hope, sweeten your imaginations, with thoughts of, ah why women are the most giddy, uncertain motions under heaven, it is neither proportion of body, virtue of mind, amplitude of fortune, greatness of blood, but only mere chanceful appetite sways them: which makes someone like a man, be it but for the paring of his nails, viah, as for inequality, art not a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: That I am, and my beneficence shall show it.

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: I know you are, by that only word beneficence, which only speaks of the future tense (shall know it, ) but may I breath in your bosoms; I only fear Tiberio will abuse his fathers trust, and so make your hopes desperate.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: How? the Prince? would he only stood cross to my wishes, he should find me an Italian.

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: How, an Italian:

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: By thy aid an Italian, dear Fawnus, thou art now wriggled into the Princes bosom, and thy sweet hand should Minister that Nectar to him, should make him immortal; Nymphadoro in direct phrase, thou shouldest murther the Prince, so revenge thine own wrongs, and be rewarded for that revenge.

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: Before the light of my eyes, I think I shall admire, wonder at you. What? have ye plots, projects, correspondences, and stratagems: why are not you in better place?
Who is this?

sp.speaker: Herod
sp.p: my eldest Brother sir Amoroso Debilidoso?

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: O I know him, God bless thine eyes sweet sir Amoroso, a rouse, a vin de monte, to health of thy chin, my dear sweet Seignior.

sp.speaker: Sir Amor.
sp.p: Pardon me sir, I drink no wine this spring.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: O no sir, he takes the diet this spring always , boy my brothers bottle.

sp.speaker: Sir Amor.
sp.l: Faith Fawn, an odd unwholesome cold, makes me still hoarse and rheumatic.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: Yes in troth a paltry murr, last morning he blew nine bones out of his nose with an odd unwholesome murr: how does my Sister your Lady, what does she breed?

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: I perceive Knight you have children, o it is a blessed assurance of heavens favour, and long lasting name to have many children.

sp.speaker: Sir Amor:
sp.p: But I have none, Fawn, now;

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: O that is most excellent, a right special happiness, he shall not be a Drudge to his cradle, a slave to his child, he shall be sure not to cherish another's blood, nor toil to advance peradventure some Rascals lust, without children a man is unclogged, his wife almost a Maid: Messalina, thou criedest out, O blessed barrenness, why once with child the very Venus of a Ladies entertainment hath lost all pleasure.

sp.speaker: Sir Amor:
sp.p: By this Ring Faunus I do hug thee with most passionate affection, and shall make my wife thank thee.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Nay my Brother grudgeth not at my probable inheritance, he means once to give a younger brother hope to see fortune.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: And yet I hear sir Amorous, you cherish your loins with high art, the only engrosser of Eringoes, prepared Cantharides, Cullises made of dissolved Pearl, and bruised Amber, the pith of Parkets, and candied Lamb-stones are his perpetual meats, Beds made of the down under pigeons wings and Goose necks, fomentations, bathes, electuaries, frictions, and all the nurses of most forcible excited concupiscence he useth with most nice and tender industry.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Pish Zoccoli, no Nymphadoro, if sir Amorous would have children, let him lie on a mattress, plough or thresh, eat onions, garlic, and leek porridge, Pharoah and his council were mistaken, and their device to hinder the increase of procreation in the Israelites, with enforcing them to much labour of body, and to feed hard, with beets, garlic, and onions (meats that make the original of man most sharpe, and taking) was absurd. No he should have given barley bread, lettuce, melons, cucumbers, huge store of veal, and fresh beef, blown up their flesh, held them from exercise, rolled them in feathers, and most severely seen them drunk once a day, then would they at their best have begotten but wenches, and in short time their generation enfeebled to nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir Am:
sp.p: O divine Fawnus, where might a man take up forty pound in a commodity of garlic, and onions? Nymphadoro thine ear.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Come what are you steering at? there is some weakness in your brother you wrinkle at thus, come prithee impart, what we are mutually incorporated, turned one into another, brewed together, come I believe you are familiar with your sister, and it were known.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: Witch, Faunus witch, why how dost dream I live? is it four score a year thinkst thou maintains my geldings, my pages, foot-cloths, my best feeding, high play, and excellent company? no it is from hence, from hence, I mint some four hundred pound a year.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Dost thou live like a porter by thy back boy?

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: As for my weak reined brother hang him, he has sore shins, damn him hetoroclite, his brain is perished, his youth spent his fodder so fast on others Cattle, that he now wants for his own in winter, I am fain to supply Fawn, for which I am supplied.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Dost thou branch him boy?

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: What else Fawn.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: What else? nay it is enough, why many men corrupt other men's wives, some their maids, others their neighbours daughters, but to lie with ones brothers wedlock, O my dear Herod it is vile and uncommon lust.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: Fore heaven I love thee to the heart, well I may praise God for my brothers weakness, for I assure thee, the land shall descend to me my little Fawn.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: To thee my little Herod? o my rare Rascal, I do find more and more in thee to wonder at, for thou art indeed; if I prosper thou shalt know what.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: What? know you not Don Zuccone the only desperately railing at his Lady that ever was confidently melancholy, that egregious idiot, that husband of the most witty, fair (and be it spoken with many men's true grief) most chaste Lady Zoya, but we have entered into a confederacy of afflicting him.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Plots have you laid? inductions, dangerous.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: A quiet bosom to my sweet Don, are you going to visit your Lady.

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: What a clock is it, is it past three?

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: Past four I assure you sweet Don.

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: O then I may be admitted, her afternoons private nap is taken, I shall take her napping. I hear there is one jealous that I lie with my own wife, and begins to withdraw his hand: I protest I vow, and you will, on my knees, I will take my sacrament on it, I lay not with her this long year, this four year; let her not be turned upon me I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: My dear Don?

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: O Faunus dost know our Lady?

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Your Lady?

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: No our Lady, for the love of charity incorporate with her, I would have all nations and degrees, all ages know our Lady, for I covet only to be undoubtedly notorious.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: For indeed sir, a repressed fame mounts like Camomile, the more trod down, the more it grows, things known common and undoubted, lose rumour.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: Sir I hope yet your conjectures may err; your Lady keeps full-face, unbated roundness, cheerful aspect, were she so infamously prostitute, her cheek would fall, her colour fade, the spirit of her eye would die.

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: O young man, such women are like Danaus tub, and indeed all women are like Achilleus, with whom Hercules wrestling, he was no sooner hurled to the earth, but he rose up with double vigour, their fall strengtheneth them.

sp.speaker: Don:
sp.p: News, news, news, news, o my dear Don be raised, be jovialed, be triumphant, ah my dear Don.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: To me first in private, thy news I prithee.

sp.speaker: Don:
sp.p: Will you be secret?

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: On my life:

sp.speaker: Don:
sp.l: As you are generous?

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.l: As I am generous:

sp.speaker: Don:
sp.p: Don Zuccones Lady is with child.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.l: Nymph: Nymph: what is it? what is the news?

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.l: You will be secret.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.l: Silence itself,

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.l: Don Zuccones Lady is with child apparently.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.l: Herod, Herod, what is the matter prithee, the news?

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.l: You must tell nobody:

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.l: As I am generous --

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.l: Don Zuccones Lady is with child apparently.

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.l: Fawn what is the whisper, what is the fools secret news?

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Truth my Lord, a thing, that beauty, that well, In faith it is not fit you know it? now, now, now.

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: Not fit I know it, as thou art baptised tell me, tell me.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Will you plight your patience to it?

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: Speak I am very block, I will not be moved, I am a very block.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: But if you should grow disquiet (as I protest, it would make a Saint blaspheme) I should be unwilling to procure your impatience.

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: Ye do, burst me burst me, burst me with longing:

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Nay faith it is no great matter, hark ye , you will tell nobody .

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: Not.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.l: As you are noble.

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.l: As I am honest.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Your Lady wife is apparently with child.

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.l: With child?

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.l: With child.

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.l: Fool.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.l: My Don.

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: With child? by the pleasure of generation, I proclaim I lay not with her this ~~ give us patience, give us patience.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Why? my Lord it is nothing to wear a fork.

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: Heaven and earth.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: All things under the Moon are subject to their mistress grace; horns, lend me your ring my Don, I will put it on my finger, now it is on yours again , why is the gold now ever the worse in lustre or fitness?

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: Am I used thus?

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Aye my Lord true, nay to be ( look ye mark ye) to be used like a dead ox, to have your own hide plucked on, to be drawn on, with your own horn, to have the Lordship of your father, the honour of your ancestors, maugre your beard, to descend to the base lust of some groom of your stable, or the page of your chamber.

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: O Phalaris thy Bull.

sp.speaker: S. Am:
sp.p: Good Don: have patience, you are not the only Cuckold, I would now be separated.

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: Alas that is but the least drop of the storm of my revenge, I will vnlegittimall the issue, what I will do , shall be horrible but to think .

sp.speaker: Hir:
sp.p: But Sir.

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: But Sir? I will do what a man of my form may do, and laugh on, laugh on, do Sir Amorous, you have a Lady too.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: But my sweet Lord.

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: Do not anger me, lest I most dreadfully curse thee, and wish thee married, o Zuccone, spit white, spit thy gall out, the only boon I crave of heaven is, but to have my honours inherited by a bastard, I will be most tyrannous, bloodily tyrannous in my revenge, and most terrible in my curses: live to grow blind with lust, senseless with use, loathed after, flattered before, hated always, trusted never , abhorred ever, and last may she live to wear a foul smock seven weeks together; heaven I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: Zoya:
sp.p: Is he gone: is he blown off ? now out upon him unsufferably jealous fool.

sp.speaker: Don:
sp.p: Lady:

sp.speaker: Zoya:
sp.p: Didst thou give him the famed report? does he believe I am with child? does he give faith?

sp.speaker: Don:
sp.p: In most sincerity, most sincerely.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Nay it is a pure fool, I can tell ye he was bred up in Germany.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: But the laughter rises, that he vows he lay not in your bed this four year with such exquisite protestations.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: That is most full truth, he hath most unjustly severed his sheets ever since the old Duke Pietro (heaven rest his soul. )

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Fie, you may not pray for the dead, it is indifferent to them what you say.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: Well said fool.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: Ever since the old Duke Pietro, the great Devil of hell torture his soul.

sp.speaker: Don:
sp.p: O Lady yet charity.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: Why? it is indifferent to them what you say fool, but does my Lord ravel out, does he fret? for pity of an afflicted Lady load him soundly, let him not work clear from vexation, he has the most dishonourably, with the most sinful, most vicious obstinacy, persevered to wrong me that were I not of a male constitution, it were impossible for me to survive it, but in madness name, let him on, I have not the weak fence of some of your soft-eyed whimpering Ladies, who, if they were used like me, would gall their fingers with wringing their hands, look like bleeding Lucresses, and shed salt water enough to powder all the beef in the Dukes larder. No, I am resolved Donna Zoya; ha; that wives were of my metal, I would make these ridiculously jealous fools, howl like a starved dog, before he got a bit, I was created to be the affliction of such an unsanctified member, and will boyle him in his own syrup.

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: Peace the wolfs ear takes the wind of us.

sp.speaker: Hero:
sp.p: The enemy is in ambush.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: If any man have the wit, now let him talk wantonly, but not bawdily; come Gallants who will be my servants: I am now very open hearted, and full of entertainment.

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: Grace me too call you mistress.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.l: Or me.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Or me.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Or me.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.l: Or all, I am taken with you all, with you all.

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: As indeed, why should any woman only love such an one, since it is reasonable, women should affect all perfection, yea, all should covet many virtues, therefore Ladies should covet many men; for as in women, so in men, some woman hath only a good eye, one can discourse beautifully, if she do not laugh, one is well favoured to her nose, another hath only a good brow, the other a plump lip, a third only holds beauty to the teeth, and there the soil alters, some peradventure hold good to the breast, and then downward turn like the dreamt of Image, whose head was gold, breast silver, thighs iron, and all beneath clay and earth, one only winks eloquently, another only kisses well, the other only talks well, a fourth only lies well: So in men, one Gallant has only a good face, another has only a grave methodical beard, and is a notable wise fellow, until he speaks, a third only makes water well, and that is a good provoking quality, one only swears well, another only speaks well, a third only does well, all in their kind good, goodness is to be affected, therefore they, it is a base thing and indeed an impossible for a worthy mind to be contented with the whole world, but most vile and abject to be satisfied with one point or prick of the world.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: Excellent Faunus I kiss thee for this, by this hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.p: I thought as well, kiss me too dear mistress.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: No, good sir Amorous your teeth hath taken rust, your breath wants airing, and indeed I love sound kissing. Come Gallants, who will run a Caranto, or leap a Leualto.

sp.speaker: He:
sp.p: Take heed Lady from offending or bruising the hope of your womb.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: No matter, now I have the sleight, or rather the fashion of it, I fear no barrenness.

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: O, but you know not your husbands aptness.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: Husband? husband? as if women could have no children without husbands.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: Aye , but then they will not be so like your husband.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: No matter, they will be like their father, it is honour enough to my husband, that they vouchsafe to call him father, and that his land shall descend to them (does he not gnash his very teeth in anguish) like our husband? I had rather they were ungroaned for, like our husband and prove such a melancholy jealous ass as he is: Does he not stamp?

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: But troth, your husband has a good face.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: Faith good enough face for a husband, come gallants I will dance to mine own whistle, I am as light now as: ah,
a kiss to you, to my sweet free servants dream on me, and adieu.

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: I shall lose my wits.

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.l: Be comforted dear Don, you have none to leese:

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: My wife is grown like a Dutch-crest always rampant, rampant, fore I will endure this affliction, I will live by raking cockles out of kennels, nay, I will run my Country, forsake my religion, go weave Fustians, or roll the wheelbarrow at Rotterdam.

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: I would be divorced despite her friends, or the oath of her Chamber maid.

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: Nay, I will be divorced in despite of them all, I will go to law with her.

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: That is excellent, nay, I would go to law.

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: Nay, I will go to law.

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: Why that is sport alone, what though it be most exacting, wherefore is money?

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: True, wherefore is money?

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: What though you shall pay for every quill, each drop of Ink, each minim, letter, tittle, comma, prick, each breath, nay, not only for thine own Orators prating, but for some other Orators silence, though thou must buy silence with a full hand, it is well known Demosthenes took above two thousand. pound once only to hold his peace, though thou a man of noble gentry, yet you must wait, and besiege his study door, which will prove more hard to be entered, than old Troy, for that was gotten into by a wooden horse, but the entrance of this may chance cost thee a whole stock of Cattle, Oues et boues et caetera pecora campi, though then thou must sit there thrust and contemned bareheaded to a grogram scribe ready to start up at the door creaking, pressed to get in, with your leave Sir, to some surly groom, the third son of a Rope maker; what of all this?

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: To a resolute mind these torments are not felt.

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: A very arrant Ass, when he is hungry will feed on though he be whipped to the bones, and shall a very arrant Ass Zuccone, be more virtuously patient, than a noble.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: No Fawn the world shall know I have more virtue, than so.

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: Do so and be wise.

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: I will I warrant thee, so I may be revenged, what care I what I do?

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.p: Call a dog worshipful,

sp.speaker: Zucc.
sp.p: Nay, I will embrace, nay I will embrace a jakes-farmer after eleven a clock at night, I will stand bare, and give wall to a Bellows mender, pawn my Lordship, sell my foot-cloth, but I will be revenged, does she think she has married an Ass?

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.l: A Fool?

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.l: A Coxcomb?

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.l: A Ninny-hammer?

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.l: A Woodcock?

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.l: A Calf?

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: No, she shall find that I have eyes.

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.l: And brain.

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.l: And nose.

sp.speaker: Herc:
sp.l: And Forehead.

sp.speaker: Zucc:
sp.p: She shall in faith Fawn, she shall, she shall, sweet Fawn, she shall in faith old boy, it joys my blood to think on it, she shall in faith; farewell loved sweet Fawn farewell, she shall in faith boy.

body.stage: Enter Gonzago, and Granuffo with Dulcimell.

sp.speaker: Gonz:
sp.p: We would be private only Faunus stay,
He is a wise fellow Daughter, a very wise fellow, for he is still just of my opinion: my Lord Granuffo, you may likewise stay for, I know you will say nothing, say on Daughter.

sp.speaker: Dul:
sp.l: And as I told you sir, Tiberio being sent,
Graced in high trust as to negotiate
His royal fathers love, if he neglect
The honour of this faith, just care of state,
And every fortune that gives likelihood
To his best hopes, to draw our weaker heart
To his own love (as protest he does)

sp.speaker: Gonza:
sp.l: I will hate the Prince with such a heat of breath.
His ears shall glow, nay, I discovered him
I read his eyes, as I can read an eye,
Though it speak in darkest Characters I can,
Can we not Fawn, can we not my Lord?
Why I conceive you now, I understand you both:
You both admire, yes, say is it not hit?
Though we are old, or so, yet we have wit.

sp.speaker: Dulc.
sp.l: And you may say, (if your wisdom please
As you are truly wise) how weak a creature
Soft woman is to bear the siege and strength,
Of so prevailing feature, and fair language,
As that of his is ever: you may add,
(If so your wisdom please, as you are wise)

sp.speaker: Gonz:
sp.p: As mortal man may be

sp.speaker: Dul:
sp.l: I am of years, apt for his love, and if he should proceed
In private urgent suit, how easy it were,
To win my love, for you may say (if so
Your wisdom please) you find in me
A very forward passion to enjoy him,
And therefore you beseech him seriously
Straight to forbear, with such close cunning art ,
To urge his too well graced suite: for you
(If so your Lordship please) may say I told you all.

sp.speaker: Gonz:
sp.l: Go to go to, what I will say or so,
Until I say none but myself shall know.
But I will say go to, does my colour rise?
It shall rise for I can force my blood
To come and go, as men of wit and state,
Must sometimes fain their love, sometimes their hate.
That is policy now, but come with this free heat,
Or this same Estro or Enthusiasm,
(For these are phrases both poetical)
Will we go rate the Prince, and make him see
Himself in us; that is our grace and wits,
Shall show his shapeless folly, vice kneels whilst virtue sits.
But see we are prevented daughter, in
It is not fit thyself should hear what I
Must speak of thy most modest wise, wise mind
For Thou art careful, sober, in all most wise.
And indeed our daughter. My Lord Tiberio
A horse but yet a Colt may leave his trot
A man, but yet a boy may well be broke,
From vain addictions, the head of Rivers stopped,
The Channel dries, he that doth dread a fire,
Must put out sparks, and he who fears a bull,
Must cut his horns off when he is a Calf,
Principiis obsta; saith a learned man
Who, though he was no Duke yet he was wise,
And had some sense or so.

sp.speaker: Tib:
sp.l: What means my Lord?
La sir, thus men of brain can speak in clouds
Which weak eyes cannot pearce; but my fair Lord
In direct phrase thus, my daughter tells me plain
You go about with most direct entreats
To gain her love, and to abuse her father,
O my fair Lord, will you a youth so blessed
With rarest gifts of fortune, and sweet graces
Offer to love a young and tender Lady,
Will you I say abuse your most wise father?
Who though he freeze in August, and his calves
Are sunk into his toes, yet may well wed our daughter
As old as he in wit: will you I say
(For by my troth my Lord I must be plain)
My daughter is but young, and apt to love
So fit a person as your proper self,
And so she prayed me tell you, will you now
Entice her easy breast to abuse your trust,
Her proper honour, and your fathers hopes?
I speak no figures, but I charge you check
Your appetite, and passions to our daughter
Before it head, nor offer conference
Or seek access, but by, and before us;
What judge you us as weak, or as unwise?
No you shall find that Venice Duke has eyes; and so think on it.

sp.speaker: Tibe:
sp.l: Astonishment and wonder, what means this?
Is the Duke sober?

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.l: Why have not you endeavoured
Courses that have seconded appetite?
And not your honour, or your trust of place,
Do you not court the Lady for yourself?

sp.speaker: Tibe:
sp.l: Fawn thou dost love me: if I have done so
It is past my knowledge, and I prithee Fawn
If thou observest, I do I know not what
Make me to know it, for by the dear light
I have not found a thought that way; I apt for love?
Let lazy idleness filled full of wine,
Heaved with meats, high fed with lustful ease
Go dote on colour, as for me: why earth a sense
I court the Lady? I was not borne in Cyprus,
I love, when? how? whom? think, let us yet keep
Our reason sound; I will think, and think, and sleep.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.l: Amazed, even lost in wondering, I rest full
Of covetous expectation: I am left
As on a rock, from whence I may discern
The giddy sea of humour flow beneath,
Upon whose back the vainer bubbles float
And forth with break, o mighty flattery
Thou easiest, commonest, and most grateful venom
That poisons Courts, and all societies,
How grateful dost thou make me, should one rail
And come to fear a vice, beware leg rings
And the turned key on thee, when if softer hand
Suppling a sore that itches (which should smart)
Free speech gains foes, base fawnings steal the heart,
Swell you imposthumed members till you burst
Since it is in vain to hinder, on I will thrust
And when in shame you fall, I will laugh from hence,
And cry, so end all desperate impudence.
Another's court shall show me where and how
Vice may be cured, for now beside myself
Possessed with almost frenzy, from strong fervour
I know I shall produce things mere divine,
Without immoderate heat, no virtues shine
For I speak strong, though strange, the dews that steep
Our souls in deepest thoughts, are Fury and Sleep.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: Faith Fawn it is my humour, the natural sin of my sanguine complexion, I am most enforcedly in love with all women, almost affecting them all with an equal flame.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: An excellent justice of an upright virtue, you love all Gods creatures with an unpartial affection.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: Right, neither am I inconstant to anyone in particular.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Though you love all in general, true, for when you vow a most devoted love to one you swear not to tender a most devoted love to another, and indeed why should any man overlove any thing, it is judgment for a man to love every thing proportionably to his virtue. I love a dog with a hunting pleasure, as he is pleasurable in hunting, my horse after a journeying easiness as he is easy in journeying, my hawk, to the goodness of his wing, and my wench----

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: How sweet Fawn, how?

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Why according to her creation, nature made them pretty, toying, idle fantastic imperfect creatures, even so I would in justice affect them, with a pretty toying idle fantastic imperfect affection, and as in deed they are only created for show and pleasure, so would I only love them for show and pleasure.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: Why that is my humour to a very thread, thou dost speak my proper thoughts.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: But Sir with what possibility can your constitution be so boundlessly amorous as to affect all women of what degree, form or complexion soever?

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: I will tell thee, for mine own part, I am a perfect Ouidian, and can with him affect all, if she be a virgin of a modest eye, shamefaced, temperate aspect, her very modesty inflames me, her sober blushes fires me, if I behold a wanton, pretty, courtly petulant Ape, I am extremely in love with her, because she is not clownishly rude, and that she assures her lover of no ignorant, dull, moving venus, be she sourly severe: I think she wittily counterfeits, and I love her for her wit, if she be learned and censures poets, I love her soul, and for her soul her body, be she a Lady of professed ignorance, o I am infinitely taken with her simplicity, I am assured to find no sophistication about her, be she slender and lean, she is the Greeks delight, be she thick and plump, she is the Italians pleasure, if she be tall, she is of a goodly form, and will print a fair proportion in a large bed, if she be short and low, she is nimbly delightful, and ordinarily quick witted, be she young she is for mine eye, be she old she is for my discourse as one well knowing, there is much amiableness in a grave matron, but be she young or old, lean, fat, short, tall, white, red, browne, nay even black, my discourse shall find reason to love her, if my means may procure opportunity to enjoy her.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Excellent Sir, nay if a man were of competent means wert not a notable delight for a man to have for every month in the year?

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: Nay for every week of the Month?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: Nay for every day of that week?

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: Nay for every hour of that day?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Nay for every humour of a man in that hour, to have a several Mistress to entertain him, as if he were Saturnine, or melancholy to have a black haired, pale faced, sallow thinking Mistress to clip him: If losel and merry, a sanguine, light tripping, singing indeed, a Mistress that would dance and caranto as she goes to embrace him, if choleric, impatient or ireful, to have a mistress with red hair, little Ferret eyes, a lean cheek, and a sharpe nose to entertain him. And so of the rest.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: O sir this were too great ambition: well I love and am beloved of a great many, for I court all in the way of honour, in the trade of marriage Fawn, but above all I affect the Princes, she is my utmost end. O I love a Lady whose beauty is joined with Fortune, beyond all, yet one of beauty, without fortune for some uses, nay one of fortune without beauty for some ends, but never any that has neither fortune nor beauty, but for necessity such a one as this is Dona Donetta. Here is one has loved all the Court just once over.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: O this is the fair Lady with the foul teeth, Natures hand shook when she was in making, for the red that should have spread her cheeks, nature let fall upon her nose, the white of her skin slipped into her eyes, and the gray of her eyes leapt before his time into her hair, and the yellowness of her hair fell without providence into her teeth.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: By the vow of my heart, you are my most only elected and I speak by way of protestation, I shall no longer wish to be, then that your only affection shall rest in me, and mine only in you.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: But if you shall love any other.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Any other, can any man, love any other that knows you, the only perfection of your sex, and astonishment of mankind.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Fie ye flatterer, go wear and understand my favour, this snail slow, but sure.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: This kiss.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: The integrity and only vow of my faith to you, ever urged your well deserved requital to me .

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: See here is another of.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Of your most only elected;

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Right Donna Garbetza.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: O I will acknowledge this is the Lady made of cutwork, and all her body like a sand-box full of holes, and contains nothing but dust, she chooseth her servants as men choose dogs, by the mouth, if they open well and full, their cry is pleasing, she may be chaste, for she has a bad face, and yet questionless she may be made a strumpet, for she is covetous.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: By the vow of my heart, you are my most only elected and I speak it by way of protestation) I shall no longer wish to be, then all your affections shall only rest in me, and all mine only in you.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Excellent, this piece of stuff is good on both sides, he is so constant he will not change his phrase.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: But shall I give faith, may you not love another?

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Another, can any man love another that knows you the only perfection of your sex, and admiration of mankind.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: Your speech flies too high, for your meaning to follow yet my mistrust shall not precede my experience, I wrought this favour for you.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: The integrity and only vow of my faith to you ever urged, your well deserved requital to me.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Why this is pure wit, nay judgment.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Why look the Fawn observe me.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: I do sir.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: I do love at this instant some nineteen Ladies all in the trade of marriage. now sir whose father dies first, or whose portion appeareth most, or whose fortune betters soonest, her with quiet liberty at my leisure will I elect, for if my humour love .

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: You profess a most excellent mystery sir;

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Fore heaven, see the Princes she that is.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Your most only elected too.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: O Aye, o Aye, but my hopes faint yet, by the vow of my heart you are my most only elected and---

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: There is a ship of fools going out, shall I prefer thee Nimphadoro thou mayst be masters mate, my father hath made Dondilo Captain, else thou shouldest have his place.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: By Jove Fawn she speaks as sharply and looks as sourly, as if she had been new squeezed out of a crab.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: How term you that lady with whom she holds discourse?

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: O Fawn, it is a Lady even above ambition, and like the vertical sun, that neither forceth others to cast shadows, nor can others force or shade her, her style is Dona Philocalia.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Philocalia, what that renowned Lady, whose ample report hath stroke wonder into remotest strangers, and yet her worth above that wonder, she whose noble industries hath made her breast rich in true glories, and undying abilities, she that whilst other ladies spend the life of earth, Time, in reading their glass, their Jewels, and the shame of Poesy lustful sonnets gives her soul meditations, those meditations wings, that cleave the air, fan bright celestial fires, whose true reflections makes her see herself and them: She whose pity is ever above her envy, loving nothing less than insolent prosperity, and pitying nothing more than virtue destitute of fortune.

sp.speaker: Nym
sp.p: There were a Lady for Ferraraes Duke, one of great blood, firm age, undoubted honour, above her sex, most modestly, artful, though naturally modest, too excellent, to be left unmatched, though few worthy to match with her.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: I cannot tell my thoughts grow busy.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: The Princes would be private, void the presence.

sp.speaker: Dulc.
sp.p: May I rest sure, thou wilt conceal a secret.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Yes madam.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: How may I rest truly assured.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Truly thus, Do not tell it me.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: Why, canst thou not conceal a secret?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Yes, as long as it is a secret, but when two know it. how can it be a secret, and indeed with what justice can you expect secrecy in me that cannot be private to yourself?

sp.speaker: Dulc.
sp.p: Faith Philocalia, I must of force trust thy silence, for my breast breaks if I confer not my thoughts upon thee.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: You may trust my silence, I can command that, but if I chance to be questioned I must speak truth, I can conceal but not deny my knowledge, that must command me.

sp.speaker: Dulc.
sp.p: Fie on these Philosophical discoursing women, prithee confer with me like a creature made of flesh and blood, and tell me, if it be not a scandal to the soul of all being proportion, that I a female of thirteen of a lightsome and civil discretion, healthy, lusty, vigorous, full and idle, should forever be shackled to the crampy shins of a wayward, dull, sour, austere, rough, rheumy, threescore and four.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Nay, threescore and ten at the least,

sp.speaker: Dulc.
sp.p: Now heaven bless me, as it is pity that every knave is not a fool, so it is shame, that every old man is not, and resteth not a widower. They say in China, when women are past child bearing, they are all burnt to make gunpowder. I wonder what men should be done withal, when they are past child-getting: yet upon my love Philocalia (which with Ladies is often above their honour) I do even dote upon the best part of the Duke.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Dulc.
sp.p: His son, yes sooth, and so love him, that I must marry him.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: And wherefore love him, so to marry him.

sp.speaker: Dulc.
sp.p: Because I love him, and because he is virtuous, I love to marry.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: His virtues.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: Aye , with him his virtues.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Aye with him, alas sweet Princes, love or virtue are not of the essence of marriage.

sp.speaker: Dulc.
sp.p: I jest upon your understanding, I will maintain that wisdom in a woman is a most foolish quality: A Lady of a good complexion naturally, well witted, perfectly bred and well exercised, in discourse of the best men, shall make fools of a thousand of these book thinking creatures, I speak it by way of justification, I tell thee, look that nobody Eavesdrop us. I tell thee I am truly learned, for I protest ignorant, and wise, for I love myself, and virtuous enough for a Lady of fifteen.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: How virtuous?

sp.speaker: Dulc.
sp.p: Shall I speak like a creature of a good healthful blood and not like one of these weak green sickness, lean physic, starvelings: First for the virtue of magnanimity, I am very valiant, for there is no heroic action so particularly noble and glorious to our sex, as not to fall to action, the greatest deed we can do is not to do, (look that nobody listen) Then am I full of patience, and can bear more than a Sumpter horse, for (to speak sensibly) what burthen is there so heavy to a Porters back , as Virginity to a well complexioned young Ladies thoughts? (look nobody hearken, ) By this hand the noblest vow is that of Virginity, because the hardest, I will have the Prince.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: But by what means sweet Madam?

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: O Philocalia, in heavy sadness and unwanton phrase, there lies all the brain work, by what means, I could fall into a miserable blank verse presently.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: But dear Madam, your reason of loving him.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: Faith only a woman's reason, because I was expressly forbidden to love him, at the first view I liked him, and no sooner had my Fathers wisdom mistrusted my liking, but I grew loath his judgment should err, I pitied he should prove a fool in his old age, and without cause mistrust me.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: But when you saw no means of manifesting your affection to him, why did not your hopes perish?

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: O Philocalia that difficulty only inflames me, when the enterprise is easy, the victory is inglorious, no let my wise aged, learned, intelligent Father, that can interpret yes, understand the language of birds, interpret the grumbling of dogs, and the conference of cats, that can read even silence, let him forbid all interviews, all speeches, all tokens, all messages, all (as he thinks) human means, I will speak to the Prince, court the Prince, that he shall understand me, nay I will so stalk on the blind side of my all knowing fathers wit, that do what his wisdom can, he shall be my only mediator, my only messenger, my only honourable spokesman, he shall carry my favours, he shall amplify my affection, nay he shall direct the Prince the means the very way to my bed, he and only he, when he only can do this, and only would not do this, he only shall do this.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Only you shall then deserve such a husband, O love how violent are thy passages.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: Pish Philocalia it is against the nature of love, not to be violent.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: And against the condition of violence to be constant.

sp.speaker: Dul:
sp.p: Constancy, constancy and patience are virtues in no living creatures but Sentinels and Anglers: here is our father.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: What did he think to walk invisibly before our eyes, if he had Giges ring I would find him.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Fore Jove you rated him with Emphasis.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Did we not shake the Prince with energy.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: With Ciceronian elocution.

sp.speaker: Gon
sp.p: And most pathetic piercing oratory.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: If he have any wit in him, he will make sweet use of it.

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: Nay, he shall make sweet use of it ere I have done, Lord what overweening fools these young men be, that think us old men sots.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Arrant Asses.

sp.speaker: Gon,
sp.p: Doting idiots, when we God wot, ha, ha, alas silly souls.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Poor weak creatures to men of approved reach.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Full years.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Of wise experience.

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: And approved wit.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p: Nay as for your wit.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Count Granuffo as I live this is a rare understander of men is he not, Faunus, this Granuffo is a right wise good Lord, a man of excellent discourse, and never speaks , his signs to me, and men of profound reach instruct abundantly, he begs suites with signs, gives thanks with signs, puts off his hat leisurely, maintains his beard learnedly, keeps his lust privately, makes a nodding leg courtly, and lives happily.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Silence is an excellent modest grace, but especially before, so instructing a wisdom, as that of your excellencies, as for his advancement, you gave it most royally, because he deserves it least duly, since to give to virtuous desert, is rather a due requital, than a Princely magnificence, when to undeservingness, it is merely all bounty and free grace.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Well spoke, it is enough, Don Granuffo, this Fawnus is a very worthy fellow, and an excellent Courtier, and beloved of most of the Princes of Christendom, I can tell you, for howsoever some severer dissembler grace him not when he affronts him in the full face, yet if he comes behind, or on the one side he will leer and put back his head upon him be sure, be you two precious to each other.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Sir myself, my family, my fortunes, are all devoted I protest most religiously to your service. I vow my whole self only proud in being acknowledged by you, but as your Creature, and my only utmost ambition is by my sword or soul to testify, how sincerely I am consecrated to your adoration.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: It is enough, art a Gentleman Fawn.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Not uneminently descended, for were the pedigrees of some fortunately mounted, searched, they would be secretly found to be of the blood of the poor Fawn.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: It is enough, you two I love heartily, for thy silence never displeaseth me, nor thy speech ever offend me: See our daughter attends us , my fair, my wise, my chaste, my duteous, and indeed, in all my daughter, (for such a pretty soul, for all the world have I been) what I think we have made the Prince to feel his error, what did he think? he had weak fools in hand, no, he shall find as wisely said Lucullus, Young men are fools, that go about to gull us .

sp.speaker: Dulc.
sp.p: But sooth my wisest father, the young Prince is yet forgetful, and resteth resolute, in his much unadvised love.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: Nay I protest whatever he fain to you (as he can fain most deeply. )

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Right we know it, for if you marked he would not once take sense of any such intent from him, O impudence, what mercy canst thou look for.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: And as I said, royally wise, and wisely royal Father.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: I think that eloquence is hereditary.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: Though he can fain, yet I presume your sense is quick enough to find him.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Quick, is it not.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Is it not Fawn. why I did know you fained, nay I do know (by the just sequence of such impudence) that he hath laid some second siege unto thy bosom, with most miraculous conveyances of some rich present to thee.

sp.speaker: Dulc.
sp.p: O bounteous heaven, how liberal are your graces to my Nesto-like father.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Is it not so, say.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.l: It is so oraculous Father, he hath now more than courted with bare Phrases.
See Father see, the very bane of honour,
Corruption of justice and Virginity,
Gifts hath he left with me, O view this scarf,
This as he called it most envied silk,
That should embrace an arm, or waste or side,
Which he much feared should never, this he left,
Despite my much resistance.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Did he so, give it me, I will give it him, I will regive his token with so sharpe advantage.

sp.speaker: Dulc.
sp.p: Nay my worthy Father, read but these cunning letters.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Letters? where, Prove you but justly loving, and conceiue me
Till justice leave the Gods I will never leave thee,
For though the Duke seem wise, he will find this strain,
Where two hearts find consent, all thwartings vain,
And darest thou then aver this writ,
O world of wenching wiles, where is thy wit!

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.l: But other talk for us were far more fit,
For see here comes the Prince Tiberio.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Daughter upon thy obedience, instantly take thy chamber

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: Dear father in all duty, let me beseech your leave, that I may but --

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Go to, go to, you are a simple fool, a very simple animal.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: Yet let me be the loyal servant of simplicity.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: What would you do? what are you wiser than your father, will you direct me?

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: Heavens forbid such insolence, yet let me denounce my hearty hatred.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: To what end?

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: Though it be but in the Princes ear, since fits not maidens blush to rail aloud,

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Go to, go to.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: Let me check his heat.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Well, well.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: And take him down dear father, from his full pride of hopes.

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.l: So, so, I say once more go in.
I will not lose the glory of reproof;
Is this the office of Ambassadors my Lord Tiberio?
Nay duty of a son, nay piety of a man,
A figure called in Art, Gradatio,
Which some learned (Climax) to court a royal Lady,
For his master, father, or perchance his friend,
And yet intend the purchase of such beauty,
To his own use.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Your Grace doth much amaze me.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: I fain, dissemble, Alas we are now grown old, weak sighted, alas anyone fools us.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: I deeply vow my Lord

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Peace, be not damned, have pity on your soul,
I confess sweet Prince for you to love my daughter,
Young and witty, of equal mixture both of mind and body,
Is neither wondrous nor unnatural,
Yet to forswear and vow against ones heart,
Is full of base, ignoble cowardice,
Since it is most plain, such speeches do contemn
Heaven, and fear men, (that is sententious now)

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: My gracious Lord, if I unknowingly have erred,

sp.speaker: Gon
sp.l: Unknowingly, can you blush my Lord:
Unknowingly, why can you write these lines,
Present this scarf, unknowingly my Lord,
To my dear daughter, um unknowingly:
Can you urge your suite, prefer your gentlest love,
In your own right, to her too easy breast:
That God knows takes too much compassion on ye?
(And so she prayed me say) unknowingly my Lord,
If you can act these things unknowingly,
Know we can know your actions so unknown,
For we are old I will not say in wit,
(For every just worth must not approve itself)
But take your scarf, for she vows she will not wear it.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Nay but my Lord.

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.l: Nay but my Lord, my Lord.
You must take it, wear it, keep it,
For by the honour of our house and blood,
I will deal wisely and be provident,
Your father shall not say I panderized,
Or fondly winked at your affection,
No we will be wise this night our daughter yields
Your fathers answer, this night we invite
Your presence therefore to a feastful waking,
Tomorrow to Ferrara you return,
With wished answer to your royal father,
Mean time as you respect our best relation
Of your fair (Granuffo bearing, is it not good?)
Of your fair bearing, rest more anxious,
(No anxious is not a good word) rest more vigilant
Over your passion, both forbear and bear,
Anechon, e apechon, that is Greek to you now,
Else your youth shall find,
Our nose not stuffed, but we can take the wind,
And smell you out, I say no more but thus,
And smell you out, what, have not we our eyes,
Our nose and ears, what are these hairs unwise?
Look to it, quos ego, a figure called Aposiopesis or Increpatio.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Prove you but justly, loving and conceive me,
Justice shall leave the gods before I leave thee:
Imagination prove as true, as thou art sweet,
And though the Duke seem wise, he will find this strain
When two hearts yield consent, all thwartings vain.
O quick deviceful strong brained Dulcimel
Thou art too full of wit to be a wife,
Why dost thou love, or what strong heat gave life
To such faint hopes? O woman thou art made
Most only of, and for deceit, thy form
Is nothing but delusion of our eyes,
Our ears, our hearts, and sometimes of our hands,
Hypocrisy and vanity brought forth,
Without male heat, thy most most monstrous being
Shall I abuse my royal fathers trust.
And make myself a scorn, the very food
Of rumour infamous, shall I that ever loathed,
A thought of woman, now begin to love,
My worthy fathers right, break faith to him that got me
To get a faithless woman?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: True my worthy Lord, your grace is vere pius.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: To rake from my good father the pleasure of his eyes,
And of his hands, imaginary solace of his fading life;

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: His life that only lives to your sole good,

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: And myself good, his life's most only end.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Which O may never end!

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Yes Fawn in time, we must not prescribe to nature everything: there is some end in everything.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: But in a woman, yet as she is a wife, she is,
Oftentimes the end of her husband.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Shall I, I say?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: Shall you I say confound your own fair hopes,
Cross all your course of life, make yourself vain,
To your once steady graveness, and all to second,
The ambitious quickness of a monstrous love,
That is only out of difficulty borne.
And followed only for the miracle,
In the obtaining, I would have ye now,
Tell her father all.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Uncompassionate vild man, shall I not pity, if I cannot love
Or rather shall I not for pity love,
So wondrous wit in so most wondrous beauty,
That with such rarest art and cunning means,
Entreats? what I think valueless, and not
Worthy but to grant my admiration,
Are fathers to be thought on in our loves .

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: True right sir, fathers or friends, a crown,
And love hath none, but all are allied to themselves alone,
Your father I may boldly say, he is an Ass,
To hope that you will forbear to swallow,
What he cannot chew, nay it is injustice truly,
For him to judge it fit, that you should starve.
For that which only he can feast his eye withal,
And not digest.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: O Fawn what man of so cold earth
But must love such a wit in such a body,
Thou last and only rareness of heavens works,
From best of man made model of the Gods:
Divinest woman, thou perfection
