Of all proportions, beauty made when Jove was blithe,
Well filled with Nectar, and full friends with man,
Thou dear as air, necessary as sleep
To careful man: woman, O who can sin so deeply,
As to be cursed from knowing of the pleasures,
Thy soft society, modest amorousness,
Yields to our tedious life. Fawn, the Duke shall not know this

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: Unless you tell him, but what hope can live in you,
When your short stay, and your most shortened conference,
Not only actions, but even looks observed,
Cut off all possibilities of obtaining.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Tush Fawn, to violence of women's love and wit,
Nothing but not obtaining is impossible,
Notumque furens quid foemina possit,

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: But then how rest you to your father true?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: To him that only can give dues, she rests most due.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: Even so he that with safety would well lurk in Courts,
To best elected ends, of force is wrung,
To keep broad eyes, soft feet, long ears, and most short tongue
For it is of knowing creatures the main Art,
To use quick hams, wide arms, and most close heart.

sp.speaker: Herc
sp.p: Why it is a most well in fashion affection Dona Garbetza, your Knight Sir Amorous is a man of a most unfortunate back, spits white, has an ill breath, and at three after dinner goes to the Bath, takes the diet, nay which is more, takes Tobacco, therefore with great authority you may cuckold him.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: I hope so, but would that friend my brother discover me, would he wrong himself, to prejudice me.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: No prejudice dear Garbetza, his brother your husband right, he cuckold his eldest brother, true, he gets her with child just.

sp.speaker: Garb.
sp.p: Sure there is no wrong in right, true and just.

sp.speaker: Herc,
sp.p: And indeed since the virtue of procreation growed hopeless in your husband, to whom should you rather commit your love and honour to, than him that is most like and near your husband his brother, but are you assured your friend and brother rests entirely constant solely to you?

sp.speaker: Garb.
sp.p: To me, O Fawn, let me sigh it with joy into thy bosom, my brother has been wooed by this and that and the other Lady to entertain them (for I have seen their letters, but his vow to me O Fawn is most immutable, unfeigning, peculiar, and indeed deserved.

body.stage: Enter Puttotta and a Page, Puttotta with a letter in his hand.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Never entreat me, never beseech me, to have pity forsooth on your Master, Master. Herod: Let him never be so daringly ambitious, as to hope with all his vows and protestations to gain my affection, gods, my discretion? has my sutlery, tapstry, laundry, made me be taken up at the Court, preferred me to a husband, and have I advanced my husband with the labour of mine own body, from the black guard, to be one of the Dukes drummers, to make him one of the Court gallants, cautel who wears perfumes, who plasters, and for why, know whose a gallant, of a chaste shirt, I become, or dares your master think I will become, or if I become, presumes your master to hope I would become one of his common feminines, no let Master. Herod brag of his brothers wife, I scorn his letters, and her leavings at my heel, in faith and so tell him.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Nay costly, dear Puttotta, mistress Puttotta, madam Puttotta, O be merciful to my languishing master, he may in time grow a great and well graced Courtier, for he wears green already, mix therefore your loves, as for madam Garbetza his brothers wife, you see what he writes there.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: I must confess he says she is a spiny, green creature, of an unwholesome barren blood and cold embrace, a bony thing of most unequal hips, uneven eyes, ill ranked teeth, and indeed one, but that she lures him he endures not, yet, for all this does he hope to dishonest me: I am for his betters, I would he should well know it, for more by many the my husband, know I am a woman of a known, sound and upright carriage, and so he shall find if he deal with me, and so tell him I pray you, what does he hope to make me one of his gills, his punks, polecats, flirts, and feminines.

body.stage: Exit as Puttotta goes out shee flinges away the letter, the page puts it vp, and as hee is talking Hercules steales it out of his pocket.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Alas my miserable master, what suds art thou washed into, thou art borne to be scorned of every carted community, and yet he will out crack a German when he is drunk, or a Spaniard after he hath eaten a Fumatho, that he has lain with that and that, and the other lady, that he lay last night in such a maidens chamber, the other night he laid in such a Countess couch, tonight he lies in such a Ladies closet, when poor I know all this while he lied in his throat.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Madam let me sigh it in your bosom, how immutable and unfainting, and indeed.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: Fawn I will undo it, rascal he shall starve for any further maintenance.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: You may make him come to the covering and recovering of his old doublets.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: He was in fair hope of proving heir to his elder brother, but he has gotten a child.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: So, you withdrawing your favour, his present means fail him, and by getting you with child, his future means forever rest despairful to him.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: O heaven that I could curse him beneath damnation, impudent varlet: by my reputation Fawn, I only loved him, because I thought I only did not love him, but as he vowed infinite beauties doted on him, alas I was a simple country Lady, wore gold buttons, trunk sleeves, and flagon bracelets, in this state of innocency was I brought up to the Court.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: And now instead of country innocency have you got court honesty, well Madam leave your brother to my placing, he shall have a special cabin in the ship of fools.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: Right, remember he got his elder brothers wife with child, and so deprived himself of the inheritance.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: That will follow him under hatches I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: And so deprived himself of inheritance, dear Fawn be my champion.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: The very scourge of your most basely offending brother.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: Ignoble villain, that I might but see thee wretched without pity and recovery well.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Stand Herod, you are full met sir.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: But not metteful sir, I am as gaunt as a hunting gelding after three trained scents, for Venus Fan I have been shaling of peasecods, upon fair Madonna have I this afternoon grafted the forked tree.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.p: Possible, fie on this satiety, it is a dull, blunt, weary, and drowsy passion; who would be a proper fellow to be thus greedily devoured and swallowed among Ladies? faith it is my torment my very rack.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Right heard, true, for imagine all a man possessed with a perpetual pleasure, like that of generation, even in the highest lusciousness, he straight sinks as unable to bear so continual, so pure, so universal a sensuality.

sp.speaker: Herod
sp.p: By even truth it is very right, and for my part would I were eunuched rather then thus sucked away with kisses, enfeebling dalliance, and O the falling sickness on them all, why did reasonable nature give so strange, so rebellious, so tyrannous, so insatiate parts of appetite to so weak a governess as woman.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Or why O custom didst thou oblige them to modesty, such cold temperance, that they must be wooed by men, courted by me why all know, they are more full of strong desires those desires most impatient of delay, or hindrance, they have more unruly passions than men, and weaker reason to temper those passions than men.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Why then hath not the discretion of nature thought it just, customary coins, old fashions, terms of honour and of modesty forsooth, all laid aside, they court not us, beseech not us, rather for sweets of love, than we them, why by Janus women are but men turned the wrong side outward.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: O sir nature is a wise workman, she knows right well that if women should woo us to the act of love, we should all be utterly shamed, how often should they take us unprovided when they are always ready.

sp.speaker: Herod
sp.p: Aye sir, right sir, to some few such unfortunate handsome fellows as myself am to my grief I know it.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Why here are two perfect Creatures, the one Nymphodoro, loves all, and my Herod here enjoys all.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Faith some score or two of Ladies or so, ravish me among them, divide my presence, and would indeed engross me, were I indeed such an Ass as to be made a Monopoly of: look sirrah what a vild hand one of them writes, who would ever take this for a. d. dearest, or read this for only, only dearest.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Here is a lie indeed.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: True, but here is another much more legible, a good secretary my most affected Herod, the utmost ambition of my hopes, and only.

sp.speaker: Her,
sp.p: There is one lie better shaped by odds.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Right, but here is a Ladies roman hand to me is beyond all, look ye, to her most elected servant, and worthy friend Herod Baldonzozo Esquire, I believe thou knowest what Countesses hand this is, I will show thee another.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: No good Herod I will show thee one now: To his most elected Mistress and worthy laundress, divine mistress Puttotta at her tent in the woodyard or else where give these.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: prithee have silence what is that.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: If my tears or vows, my doubtless protestations on my knees.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Good hold.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: Fair and only loved laundress.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Forbear I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: Might move thy stony heart to take pity on my sighs

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Do not shame me to the day of judgment.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: Alas I write it in passion, alas thou knowest besides my loathed sister thou art.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: For the Lords sake.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: The only hope of my pleasure, the only pleasure of my hopes, be pleased therefore to.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Cease I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Pish, never blush man, it is an uncourtly quality, as for thy lying, as long as there is policy in it, it is very passable, wherefore has heaven given man tongue but to speak to a man's own glory? He that cannot swell bigger then his natural skin, nor seem to be in more grace than he is, has not learned the very rudiments or A. B. C. of courtship.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Upon my heart Fawn thou pleasest me to the soul, why look you for mine own part I must confess.
See here is the Dukes fool

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: A board a board a board all manner of fools of country tie or country of what degree sex or nature.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.l: fool.

sp.speaker: Don:
sp.l: Herod.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: What, are ye full straighted, is your ship well fooled?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: O it was excellently thronged full, a Justice of peace though he had been one of the most illiterate asses in a Country could hardly have got a hanging cabin. O we had first some log fortunate great Politicians that were so sottishly paradised as to think when popular hate seconded Princes displeasure to them, any unmerited violence could seem to the world in justice, some purple fellows whom chance reared, and their own deficiencies of spirit hurled down, we had some courtiers that over bought their offices and yet durst fall in love, Priests that forsook their functions to avoid a thwart stroke with a wet finger. But now alas Fawn, now there is place and place.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Why how gat all these forth, was not the warrant strong ?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Yes, yes, but they got a supersede as all of them proved themselves either knaves or mad men and so were all let go, there is none left now in our ship, but a few Citizens, that let their wives keep their shop books, some philosophers, and a few Critiques; one of which Critiques has lost his flesh with fishing at the measure of Plautus verses, another has vowed to get the consumption of the lungs, or to leave to posterity the true orthography and pronunciation of laughing, a third hath melted a great deal a suet, worn out his thumbs with turning, read out his eyes and studied his face out of a sanguine into a meagre sprawling phlegmy loathsomeness, and all to find but why mentula should be the feminine gender since the rule is Propria quae maribus in tribuuntur mascula dicat. These Philosophers, Critiques and all the mads we could find at sixteen are all our fraught how.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: O then, your ship of fools is full.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: True the maids at seventeen fill it.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Fill it quoth you alas we have very few and these we were fain to take up in the country too.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: But what Philosophers have ye.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: O very strange fellows one knows nothing, dares not aver, he lives, goes, sees, feels.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: A most insensible Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Another that there is no present time, and that one man Today, and tomorrow is not the same man, so that he that yesterday owed money today owes none, because he is not the same man.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: Would that Philosopher would hold good in law.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: But why has the Duke thus laboured to have all the fools shipped out of his dominions.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Marry because he would play the fool himself alone without any rival.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Ware your breech fool.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I warrant thee old lad it is the privilege of poor fools to talk before an intelligencer, marry if I could fool myself into a Lordship as I know some have fool themselves out of a Lordship were I grown some huge fellow and got the leer of the people upon me if the fates had so decreed it, I should talk treason though I never opened my lips.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: In fatis agimur, cedite fatis, but how runs rumour what breath is strongest in the Palace, now I think you know all.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Yes we fools think we know all the Prince hath audience tonight, is feasted and after supper is entertained with no comedy mask or barriers but with.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: What I prithee?

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: What I prithee?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: With a most new and special shape of delight.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: What for Jove's sake?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Marry gallants, a session, a general council of love summoned in the name of Don Cupid to which upon pain of their mistress displeasure shall appear all favour wearers, sonnet mongers, health drinkers, and neat in riches of barbers, and perfumers, and to conclude all that can wehee or wag the tail, are upon grievous pains of their back summoned to be assistant in that Session of love .

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Hold, hold, do not pall the delight before it come to our palate, and what other rumour keeps air on men's lungs.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Other egregiousness of folly have you not heard of Don Zucone.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: What of him good fool.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: He is separated.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Divorced.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: That salt that criticism, that very all epigram of a woman, that Analysis, that compendium of witness.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Now lesu what words the fool has.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: We have still such words but I will not unshake the jest before it be ripe and therefore kissing your worships fingers in most sweet terms without any sense and with most fair looks without any good meaning I most court-like take my leave situs manus devostro seigniora.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: Stay fool we will follow thee, for fore heaven we must prepare ourselves for this session.

body.stage: Enter Zuccone pursued by Zoya on her knees attended by Ladies

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: I will have no mercy, I will not relent, justice beard is shaven, and it shall give thee no hold, I am separated and I will be separated.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.l: Dear my Lord husband.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Hence creature, I am none of thy husband or father of thy bastard, no I will be tyrannous and a most deep revenger the order shall stand ha, thou Quean I have no wife now.

sp.speaker: Zoy.
sp.l: sweet my Lord.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Hence avaunt I will marry a woman with no womb, a creature with two noses, a wench with no hair rather then remarry thee, nay I will first marry, mark me I will first marry, observe me, I will rather marry a woman that with thirst drinks the blood of man: nay, heed me a woman that will thrust in crowds, a lady that being with child ventures the hope of her womb, nay gives two crowns for a room to behold a goodly man three parts alive quartered, his privities hackled off, his belly launched up. Nay I will rather marry a woman to whom this smoking, hideous, cloudful, horrid, though most just spectacles, are very lust, rather, then reaccept thee, was I not a handsome fellow from my foot to my feather, had I not wit, nay, which is more, was I not a Don, and didst thou Acteen me, did I not make thee a Lady.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: And did she not make you a more worshipful thing, a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: I married thee in hope of children.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: And has not she showed herself fruitful that was got with child without help of her husband.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Ha thou ungrateful immodest, unwise, and that God is my witness I have loved , but go thy ways twist with whom thou wilt for my part thou hast spun a fair thread, who will kiss thee now who will court thee now, who will have thee now?

sp.speaker: Zoy.
sp.p: Pity the frailty of my sex sweet Lord.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: no pity is a fool and I will not wear his coxcomb, I have vowed to loath thee, the Irish man shall hate aqua-vitae, the welsh man cheese, the dutch man shall loath salt butter before I relove thee, does the babe pule? thou shouldest have cried before, it is too late now, no the trees in autumn shall sooner call back the spring with shedding of their leaves; than thou reverse my just irrevocable hatred with thy tears, away go vaunt.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Nay but most of this is your fault that for many years only upon mere mistrust severed your body from your Lady and in that time gave opportunity turned a jealous ass, and hired some to try and tempt your Ladies honour whilst she with all possible industry of apparent merit divering your unfortunate suspicion.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: I know it I confess, all this I did and I do glory in it, why? cannot a young Lady for many months keep honest? no, I misthought it, my wife had wit, beauty, health, good birth, fair clothes and a passing body, a Lady of rare discourse, quick eye, sweet language, alluring behaviour, and exquisite entertainment. I misthought it, I feared, I doubted, and at the last I found it out, I praise my wit I knew I was a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: An excellent wit.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: True Fawn, you shall read of few dunces that have had such a wit I can tell you, and I found it out, and I was a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: which now you have found you will not be such an ass as Caesar, great Pompey, or Lucullus, Anthony, or Cato and divers other Romans cuckolds, who all knew it, and yet were never divorced upon it , or like that smith god Vulcan who having taken his wife, yet was presently appeased, and entreated to make an Armour for a bastard of hers.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: No the Romans were asses, and thought that a woman might mix her thigh with a stranger wantonly, and yet still love her husband matrimonially.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: As indeed they say a many married men, lie sometime with strange women , whom, but for the instant use, they abhor.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: And as for Vulcan it was humanity more than human, such excess of goodness for my part shall only belong to the Gods.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Ass for you.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: As for me my Fawn I am a bachelor now.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: But you are a Cuckold still, and one that knows himself to be a Cuckold

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Right, that is it and I knew it not, it were nothing and if I had not pursued it too, it had lain in oblivion, and shadowed in doubt, but now I have blazed it.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: The world shall know what you are.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: True, I will pocket up no horns, but my revenge shall speak in thunder.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Indeed I must confess I know twenty are Cuckolds and decently and stately enough a worthy gallant spirit (whose virtue suppresseth his mishap) is lamented but not disesteemed by it: Yet the world shall know.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: I am none of those silent Coxcombs it shall not.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: And although it be no great part of injustice, for him to be struck with the scabbard that has struck with the blade (for there is few of us but hath made some one Cuckold or other)

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: True I have done it myself.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: yet.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Yet I hope a man of wit may prevent his own mishap or if he can prevent it.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Yet.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Yet make it known yet, and so known that the world may tremble with only thinking of it. Well Fawn whom shall I marry now, O heaven! that God made for a man no other means of procreation and maintaining the world peopled but by women, O that we could get one another with child Fawn, or like flies procreate with blowing, or any other way than by a woman, by women who have no reason in their love, or mercy in their hate, no rule in their pity, no pity in their revenge, no Judgement to speak, and yet no patience to hold their tongues; man's opposite, the more held down they swell, above them naught but will beneath them naught but hell.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Or that since heaven hath given us no other means to allay our furious appetite, no other way of increasing our progeny, since we must entreat and beg for assuagement of our passions, and entertainment of our affections, why did not heaven make us a nobler creature than women to show unto, some admirable, deity of an uncorruptible beauty that be worth our knees, the expense of our heat, and the crinkling of our.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: But that we must court, sonnet, flatter, bribe, kneel, sue to so feeble and imperfect, inconstant , idle, vain, hollow, bubble, as woman is. O my face.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: O my Lord look who here comes.

body.stage: Enter Zoya supported by a gentleman vssher followed by Herod and Nymphadora with much state, soft musik playing.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Death a man, is she delivered?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Delivered, yes. O my Don. delivered, yes Dona Zoya the grace of society, the music of sweetly agreeing perfection, more clearly chaste then ice or frozen rain, that glory of her sex, that wonder of wit, that beauty more fresh than any cool and trembling wind, that now only wish of a man is delivered, is delivered.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: how

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: From Don. Zuc. that dry scaliness, that sarpego, that barren drought and shame of all humanity.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: What fellow is that.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Don. Zuc. your sometime husband.

sp.speaker: Zoy.
sp.p: alas poor creature.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: The Princes prays your company.

body.stage: All but Hercules, Zuccone, Herod, and Nim. depart.

sp.speaker: Zoy.
sp.p: I wait upon her pleasure.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Gentlemen why hazard you your reputation in shameful company with such a branded creature,

sp.speaker: Herod
sp.p: Miserable man whose fortune were beyond tears to be pitied, but that thou art the ridiculous author of thine own laughed at mischief.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Without paraphrase your meaning.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: Why thou woman's fool?

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.l: Good gentlemen let one die but once.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Was not thou most curstfully mad to sever thyself from such an unequalled rarity.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Is she not a strumpet? Is she not with Child?

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.p: yes, with feathers.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: why weakness of reason, couldst not perceive all was feigned to be rid of thee?

sp.speaker: Zuc
sp.p: Of me.

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.l: she with child, untrod snow is not so spotless

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.l: Chaste as the first voice of a new borne infant,

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: know she grew loathing of thy jealousy,

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.l: thy most pernicious curiosity,

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: whose suspicions made her unimitable graces motive of thy base jealousy.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.l: why beast of man?

sp.speaker: Nym,
sp.p: wretched above expression that snoredest over a beauty which thousands desired, neglect her bed, for whose enjoying a very saint would have sued.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: defamed her.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: suggested privily against her.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: gave foul language publicly of her.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: and now lastly done that for her which she only prayed for, and wished as wholesome air for, namely to be from such an unworthy.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.l: senseless.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: injurious.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: malicious.

sp.speaker: Herod
sp.l: suspicious.

sp.speaker: Nym
sp.l: misshaped.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: ill languaged

sp.speaker: Nym:
sp.l: ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: jealous.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.l: arch coxcomb as thou art.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: O I am sick, my blood he has the cramp, my stomach overturns; O I am very sick.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: why my sweet Don, you are no cuckold.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: that is the grief on it Hercules, that is the grief of it that I have wronged so sweet (and now in my knowledge) so delicate a creature, O methinks I embrace her yet.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: alas my Lord you have done her no wrong, no wrong in the world, you have done her a pleasure, a great pleasure, a thousand gentlemen, nay dukes will be proud to accept your leavings, your leavings, now is she courted, this heir sends her jewels, that lord proffers her jointures, the other knight proclaims challenges, to maintain her, the only not beautiful, but very beauty of women.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: but I shall never embrace her more:

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: nay that is true, that is most true (I would not afflict you, only think how unrelentless you were to her but supposed fault.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: O it is true, too true.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: think how you scorned her tears,

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: most right.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: Tears that were only shed I would not vex you in very grief to see you covet your own shame.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.l: Too true, too true.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: For indeed she is the sweetest modest soul, the fullest of pity.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.l: O Aye O Aye .

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: The softness and very courtesy of her sex as one that never loved any .

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: But me.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: So much that he might hope to dishonour her, nor any so little that he might fear she disclaimed him. O the graces made her a fowl, as soft as spotless down upon the swans fair breast that drew bright Cythereas chariot, yet think (I would not vex you) yet think how cruel you were to her.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: As a Tiger, as a very Tiger.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: And never hope to be reconciled, never dream to be reconciled, never

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Never , alas good Faw, what wouldst wish me to do now?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Faith go hang yourself my Don, that is best sure.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
Herc.
sp.p: There is a modest matron like creature.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: What years Faw.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Some four score wanting one.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: A good sober age, is she wealthy?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Very wealthy.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: She has three hairs on her scalp and four teeth in her head, a brow wrinkled and puckered like old parchment half burnt, she has had eyes, no woman's Jawbones are more apparent, her sometimes envious lips, now shrink in, and give her nose and her chin leave to kiss each other, very moistly as for her revered it seldom opens, but the very breath that flies out of it infects the fowls of the air, and makes them drop down dead, her breasts hang like cobwebs, her flesh will never make you cuckold, her bones may.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: But is she wealthy

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Very wealthy.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: And will she have me, art sure?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: No sure, she will not have you, why do you think that a waiting woman of three bastards, a strumpet nine times carted or a hag whose eyes shoot poison, that has been an old witch and is now turning into a gib cat, that, will have you marry the contempt of women and the shame of men, that has afflicted, contend, so choice a perfection as Dona Zoyas?

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Alas Fawn I confess what wouldst have me do.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Hang yourself, you shall not, marry you cannot, I will tell ye what you shall do, there is a ship of fools setting forth if you see good means and entreat hard, you may obtain a passage man be masters mate I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Fawn, thou art a scurvy bitter knave, and dost flout Dons to their faces, it was thou flatteredest me to this, and now thou laughedest at me, dost? though indeed, I had a certain proclivity, but thou madest me resolute, dost grin and girn, O you comforters of life, helps in sickness, joys in death, and preservers of us, in our children, after death, women have mercy on me,

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: O my Don, that God made no other means, of procreation but by these women, I speak it not to vex you.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: O Fawn, thou hast no mercy in thee, dost thou leer on me, well, I will creep upon my knees to my wife, dost laugh at me? dost girn at me? dost smile? dost leer on me, dost thou? O I am an Ass true, I am a Coxcomb, well, I am mad, good: A mischief on your cogging tongue, your soothing throat, your oily jaws, your supple thumbs, your dissembling smiles, and O the grand Devil of you all: when mischief favours our fortunes, and we are miserable, though justly wretched,
sp.l: More pity, comfort, and more help we have,
In foes professed, than in a flattering knave.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Thus few strike sail until they run on shelf,
The eye sees all things but his proper self,
In all things curiosity hath been,
Vicious at least, but herein most pernicious,
What madness is it to search and find a wound,
For which there is no cure, and which unfound
Never rankles, whose finding only wounds,
But he that upon vain surmise forsakes
His bed thus long, only to search his shame,
Gives to his wife, youth, opportunity,
Keeps her in idle full deliciousness,
Heats and inflames imagination,
Provokes her to revenge with churlish wrongs,
What should he hope but this, why should it lie in women,
Or even in chastity itself, since chastities a female,
To avoid desires so ripened, such sweets so candied:
But she that hath not borne such mass of wrongs,
Out dured all persecutions, all contempts,
Suspects, disgrace, all wants, and all the mischief,
The baseness of a cankered churl could cast upon her,
With constant virtue, best feigned chastity,
And in the end turns all his jealousies,
To his own scorn, that Lady I implore,
It may be lawful not to praise, but even adore.

body.stage: Enter Gonzago, Granuffo, with full state. Enter the Cornets sounding.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Are our sports ready, is the Prince at hand?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: The Prince is now arrived at the Court gate.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: What means our daughters breathless haste .

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: O my princely father now or never let your princely wisdom appear.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Fear not our daughter, if it rest within human reason I warrant thee, no I warrant thee, Granuffo if it rest in man's capacity, speak dear daughter.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: My Lord the Prince.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: The Prince, what of him dear daughter?

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: O Lord what wisdom our good parents need, to shield their chickens from deceits, and wiles of kite like youth.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Her very phrase displays whose child she is.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: Alas had not your grace been provident, a very Nestor in advise and knowledge, hah, where had you poor Dulcimel been now, what veins had not I been drawn into?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Fore God, she speaks very passionately. Alas daughter, heave gives every man his talent, indeed virtue and wisdom are not fortunes gifts, therefore those that fortune cannot make virtuous, she commonly makes rich, for our own part we acknowledge heavens goodness, and if it were possible, to be as wise again as we are, we would near impute it to ourselves : for as we be flesh and blood, alas we are fools, but as we are Princes, Scholars, and have read Cicero the Orator I must confess there is another matter in it , what of the Prince dear daughter?

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: Father do you see that tree, that leans just on my chamber window?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: What of that tree?

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: O sir, but note the policy of youth, mark but the stratagems of working love, The prince salutes me, and thus greets my ear.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Speak softly, he is entered.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: Although he knew, I yet stood wavering, what to elect, because though I affected, yet destitute of means to enjoy each other, impossibility of having, might kill our hope and which our hope desires to enjoy. Therefore to avoid all faint excuses, and vain fears, thus he devised to Dulcimels chamber window. A well grown plantain spreads his happy arms, by that in depth of night one may ascend, (despite all fathers jealousies and fears) into her bed.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Speak low, the Prince both marks and listens.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: You shall provide a Priest (quoth he) in truth I promised and so you well may tell him, for I temporised and only held him off.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Politically, our daughter to a hair.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.l: With full intention to disclose it all, to your preventing wisdom.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Aye let me alone for that: but when intends he this invasion? when will this Squirrel clime?

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.l: O Sir in that is all, when but this night?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: This night?

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: This very night when the court revels had over waked your spirits, and made them full of sleep, then ~~

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Then verbum sat sapienti: go take your chamber, down upon your knees, thank god your father is no foolish sot but one that can foresee and see.
sp.l: my Lord we discharge your presence from our Court.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: What means the Duke?

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.l: And if tomorrow past you rest in Vrbin, the privilege of an ambassador is taken from you.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Good your grace some reason?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: What, twice admonished twice again offending?
And now grown blushless you promised to get into
Her chamber, she to get a priest,
Indeed she wished me tell you she confessed it,
And there despite all fathers Jealous fears,
To consummate full joys: know Sir our daughter
Is our Daughter, and has wit at will
To gull a thousand easy things like you:
But Sir depart, the Parliament prepared
Shall on without you; all the Court this night
Shall triumph that our Daughter has escaped
Her blowing up; your end you see,
We speak but short but full Socratice

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: What should I think, what hope, what but imagine of these engines?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: Sure sir the Lady loves you
With violent passion, and this night prepares
A priest with nuptial rights to entertain you
In her most private chamber.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: This I know
With too much torture, since means are all unknown
To come unto these ends where is, this her chamber?
Then what means shall without suspicion
Convey me to her chamber? O these doubts;
end in despair

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Sir sir this Plantain was not planted here
To get into my Daughters chamber: and so she prayed me tell you
What though the main arms spread into her window?
And easy labour climes it: Sir know
She has a voice to speak, and bid you welcome;
With so full breast that both your ears shall hear of it,
And so she prayed me tell you. Have we no brain?
Youth thinks that age: Age knows that youth is vain,

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Why now I have it Fawn, the way, the means, and meaning, good Duke if it were not for pity I could laugh at thee, Dulcimel I come, thine most miraculously, I will now begin to sigh, read Poets, look pale, go neatly, and be most apparently in love; as for --

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: As for you old father.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Alas he and all know, this an old saw hath been;
Faiths breach for love and kingdoms is no sin.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: Where are we now Cyllenian Mercuris?
And thou quick messenger of Jove's broken pate
Aide and direct us: you better Start to knowledge
Sweet constellations, that effect pure oil,
And holy vigil of the pale cheeked Muses,
Give your best influence, that with able sprite,
We may correct, and please, giving full light,
To every angle of this various fence,
Works of strong birth, end better than commence.

body.stage: Whilest the Act is a playing, Hercules and Tiberio enters, Tiberio climes the tree, and is receiued aboue by Dulcimel, Philocalia and a Priest: Hercules stayes beneath.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Thou mother of chaste dew nights modest lamp,
Thou by whose faint shine the blushing lovers,
Join glowing cheeks, and mix their trembling lips,
In vows well kissed, rise all as full of splendour,
As my breast is of joy ~~ You genital,
You fruitful well mixed heats, O bless the sheets
Of yonder chamber, that Ferraraes Dukedom,
The race of princely issue be not cursed,
And ended in abhorred barrenness.
At length kill all my fears, nor let it rest,
Once more my tremblings, that my too cold son,
(That ever scorner of human loves, )
Will still contemn the sweets of marriage,
Still till our hope of name in his dull coldness,
Let it be lawful to make use ye sowers
Of human weakness, that pursueth still,
What is inhibited, and most affects,
What is most difficult to be obtained,
So we may learn, that nicer love is a shade:
It follows fled, pursued flies as afraid,
And in the end close all the various errors,
Of passages most truly comical:
In moral learning with like confidence,
Of him that vowed good fortune of the scene,
shall neither make him fat, or bad make lean.

sp.speaker: Dondol.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Why dost laugh fool, here at nobody with thee.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Why, therefore do I laugh, because there is nobody with me, would I were a fool alone, I faith I am come to attend let me go, I am sent to the Princes, to come and attend her father to the end of Cupids Parliament.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Why, have they sat already upon any statutes.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Sat Aye , all is agreed in the nether house;

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Why, are they divided?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: O Aye in Cupids Parliament, all the young gallants are a the nether house, and all the old seigniors that can but only kiss are of the upper house: is the Princes above?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: No sure, I think the Princes is beneath, man, have they supped fool?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: O yes, the confusion of tongues, at the large Table is broke up , for see the presence fills; A fool, a fool, a fool my Coxcomb for a fool.

body.stage: Enter Sir Amaros, Herod Nymphadon, Garbetza, Donella and Poueia.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Stop Ass, what is matter idiot?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: O gallants, my fools that were appointed to wait on have launched out their ship to purge their stomachs on the water, and before Jupiter I fear, they will prove defective in their attendance.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Pish, fool, they will float in with the next tide.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Aye , but when is, that let us see mine Almanac or prognostication.

sp.speaker: Sir Am:
sp.l: What, is this for this year?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: In true wisdom sir it is, Let me see the moon, fore pity, it is in the wayne, what grief is this that so great a planet should ever decline or lose splendour ~~ full sea at ~~

sp.speaker: S. Am.
sp.p: Where is the sign now fool?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: In Capricorn, Sir Amoroso.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: What strange thing does this Almanac speak of fool?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Is this your lady Sir Amorous?

sp.speaker: S. Am.
sp.p: It is, kiss her fool.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: You may kiss her now, she is married.

sp.speaker: S. Am.
sp.p: So he might have done before,

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: In sober modesty Sir, I do not use to do it behind.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Good fool be acquainted with this lady too , she is of a very honest nature I assure thee.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I easily believe you sir, for she hath a very good face, I assure ye.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: But what strange things does thy Almanac speak of good fool?

sp.speaker: Don:
sp.p: That this year no child shall be begotten, but shall have a true Father.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.p: Tha&H62; is good news in faith, I am glad I got my wife with child this year,

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Why Sir Amorous this may be, and yet you not the true father, may it not Herod?

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: But what more says it good Fawn?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Faith Lady very strange things, it says, that some Ladies of your hair, shall have feeble hams, short memories and very weak eye sight, so that they shall mistake their own Page, or even brother in law, sometimes for their husbands.

sp.speaker: S. Am.
sp.p: Is that all Fawn?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: No sir Amorous, here is likewise prophesied a great scarcity of Gentry to ensue, and that some Bores shall be dubbed Sir Amoroso. A great scarcity of Lawyers is likewise this year to ensue, so that some one of them shall be entreated to take fees a both sides.

body.stage: Enter Don Zuccone following Dona Zoia on his knees.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Most dear, dear Lady, wife, Lady, wife, O do not but look on me, and have some mercy.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: I will have no mercy, I will not relent.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: The order shall stand, I am separated, and I will be separated.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Dear, my love, wife.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: Hence fellow, I am none of thy wife, no I will be tyrannous and a most deep revenger, the order shall stand, I will marry a fellow that keeps a fox in his bosom, a goat under his arm holes, and a polecat in his mouth, rather than reaccept thee.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Alas, by the Lord Lady what should I say, as heaven shall bless me what should I say?

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Kneel and cry man.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: Was I not handsome, generous, honest enough from my foot to my feather, for such a fellow as thou art?

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Alas I confess I confess.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: But go thy ways and wive with whom thou wilt for my part, thou hast spun a fair thread, who will kiss thee now? who will court thee now? who will have thee now?

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Yet be a woman and for Gods sake help me.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: And do not stand too stiffly.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: And do not stand too stiffly, do you make an Ass of me, but let these rascals laugh at me, Alas what could I do withal, it was my destiny that I should abuse you.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: So it is your destiny, that I should thus revenge your abuse: No the Irishman shall eat Aqua-vitae, the Welshman cheese, and the Dutchman salt butter before I will love or receive thee, does he cry? does the babe pule, it is too late now, thou shouldest have cried before, it is too late now, go bury thy head in silence, and let oblivion be thy utmost hope.

body.stage: The Courtiers addresse themselues to dauncing, whilst the Duke enters with Granuffo, and takes his state.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Gallants to dancing, loud music, the dukes upon entrance.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Are the sports ready.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Ready.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: It is enough, of whose invention is this parliament.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Ours.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: It is enough this night we will exult, O let this night
Be ever memorised with prouder triumphs,
Let it be writ in lasting Character,
That this night our great wisdom did discover
So close a practise, that this night I say,
Our policy found out, nay dashed the drifts
Of the young Prince, and put him to his shifts,
Nay past his shifts, fore Jove we could make a good Poet.
Delight us on we, dare our princely ear
We are well pleased to grace him, then scorn fear .
sp.stage: Cornets playing. Drunkennes, Sloth, Pride, & Plenty leade Cupid to his state, who is followed by Folly, Warre, Beggary and Slaughter
sp.l: Stand it is wisdom to acknowledge ignorance,
Of what we know not, we would not now prove foolish.
Expound the meaning of your show.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Triumphant Cupid that sleeps on the soft cheek,
Or rarest beauty, whose throne is in Ladies eyes,
Whose force writhed lightning from Jove's shaking hand,
Forced strong Alcides to resign his club,
Plucked Neptune's trident from his mighty arm,
Unhelmed Mars, he (with these trophies borne,
Led in by Sloth, Pride, Plenty Drunkenness.
Followed by Folly, War, Laughter, Beggary,
Takes his fair throne, sit pleased for now we move,
And speak not for our glory, but for love.

body.stage: Hercules takes a bowle of wine.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.p: A pretty figure, what, begins this session with ceremony?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: With a full health to our great Mistress Venus,
Let every state of Cupids parliament,
Begin the session, Et quod bonum faust umque sit precor.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Give it us, we will pledge, nor shall a man that lives,
In charity refuse it, I will not be so old,
As not be graced to Cupid, honour give it us full,
When we were young, we could have trolled it off.
Drunk down a Dutchman.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: It is lamentable, pity your grace has forgot it: Drunkenness, O it is a most fluent and swelling virtue, sure the most just of all virtues, it is justice itself, for if it chance to oppress and take too much, it presently restores it again . It makes the king and the peasant equal, for if they are both drunk alike, they are both beasts alike: As for that most precious light of heaven Truth, if time be the father of her, I am sure drunkenness is oftentimes the mother of her, and brings her forth, Drunkenness brings all out, for it brings all the drink out of the pot, all the wit out of the pate, and all the money out of the purse.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: My Lord Granuffo, this Fawn is an excellent fellow.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Silence.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: I warrant you for my Lord here.

sp.speaker: Cupid
sp.p: Since multitude of laws are signs either of much tyranny in the prince, or much rebellious disobedience in the subject, we rather think it fit to study, how to have our old laws thoroughly executed, than to have new statutes comborously invented.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Afore Jove he speaks very well.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: O sir, love is very eloquent, makes all men good Orators, himself then must needs be eloquent.

sp.speaker: Cupid
sp.p: Let it therefore be the main of our assembly, to survey our old laws, and punish their transgressions, for that continually the complaints of lovers ascend up to our deity, that love as abused, and basely bought and sold, beauty corrupted, affection feigned, and pleasure herself sophisticated. That young Gallants are proud in appetite, and weak in performance, that young Ladies are fantastically inconstant, old Ladies impudently unsatiate: wives complain of unmarried women, that they steal the dews belonging to their sheets: and maids make exclaim upon wives, that they unjustly engross all into their own hands, as not content with their own husbands, but also purloining that which should be their comfort: Let us therefore be severe in our justice: And if any of what degree soever have approvedly offended, let him be instantly unpartially arrested and punished, read our statutes.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: A statute made in the five thousand four hundred, threescore and three year of the easeful reign of the mighty potent Don Cupid Emperor of sighs, and protestations, great King of kisses, Archduke of dalliance, and sole loved of Her for the maintaining and relieving of his old soldiers, manned, or dismembered in love.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Those that are lightly hurt, shame to complain: those that are deeply struck, are past recovery.

sp.speaker: Cupid.
sp.p: On to the next.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: An Act against the plurality of Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Read.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Whereas some over amorous and unconscionable covetous young gallants without all grace of Venus, or the fear of Cupid in their minds, have at one time engrossed the care or cures of divers mistresses, with the charge of Ladies, into their own tenure or occupation, whereby their mistresses must of necessity be very ill and unsufficiently served, and likewise many able portly Gallants, live unfurnished of competent entertainment to the merit of their bodies: and whereas likewise some other greedy strangers have taken in the purlieus, outset land, and the ancient commons of our sovereign Liege Don Cupid, taking in his very high ways, and enclosing them and annexing them to their own Lordships, to the much impoverishing and putting off divers of Cupids true hearts and loyal subjects, to base and abominable shifts. Be it therefore enacted by the sovereign authority and erected ensign of Don Cupid, with the assent of some of the Lords, most of the Ladies, and all the Commons, that what person or persons soever shall in the trade of honour, presume to wear at one time two ladies favours, or at one time, shall earnestly court two women in the way of marriage, or if any under the degree of a Duke, shall keep above twenty women of pleasure, a Dukes brother fifteen, a Lord ten, a knight or a Pensioner, or both four, a gentleman two, shall ipso facto, be arrested by follies mace, and instantly committed to the ship of fools, without either bail or main prize, quadragesimo nono. Cupidinis sempervnius. Nymphadoro to the bar.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Shame a folly, will Fawn now turn an informer? does he laugh at me?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Domina Garbetza, did he not ever protest, you were his most only elected Mistress.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: He did.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Domina Donella, did he not ever protest you were his most only elected Mistress?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: He did.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Domina Poueia, did he not ever protest, that you were his most only elected Mistress.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.p: He did.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Mercy.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Our mercy is nothing, unless some Lady will beg thee.

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.p: Out upon him, dissembling perfidious liar.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Indeed it is no reason Ladies should beg liars.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: Thus he that loveth many if once known,
Is justly plagued to be believed of none.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: An act against counterfeiting of Cupids royal coin, and abusing his subjects with false money. To the bar Sir Amorous. In most lamentable form complaineth to your blind celsitude, your distressed Orators, the women of the world, that in respect that many spend thrifts, who having exhausted and wasted their substance, and in stranger parts have with empty shows, treasonably purchased Ladies affections, without being of ability to pay them for it with currant money, and therefore have deceitfully sought to satisfy them with counterfeit metal, to the great displeasure, and no small loss of your humblest subjects. May it therefore with your pitiful assent be enacted, that what Lord, Knight, or gentleman soever, knowing himself insufficient, bankrupt, exhausted and wasted, shall traitorously dare to entertain any lady, as wife, or mistress, ipso facto to be severed from all commercement with women, his wife or mistress in that state offending, to be forgiven with a pardon of course, and himself instantly to be pressed to sail in the ship of fools, without either bail or main-prise.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Sir Amorous is arrested.

sp.speaker: Don, Amar.
sp.p: Sir judgment of the country.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: I take my oath upon thy brothers body, it is none of thine.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: By the heart of dissemblance, this Fawn has wrought with us as strange Taylors work in corporate cities, where they are not free all inward, inward, he lurked in the bosom of us, and yet we know not his profession: Sir let me have counsel?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: It is in great case, you may have no counsel.

sp.speaker: Don. Amor.
sp.p: Sir death a justice, are we in Normandy, what is my Ladies doom then?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Acquitted by the right penalty of the statute, hence and in thy ignorance be quietly happy, away with him. on.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: An Act against forgers of love letters, false braggarts of ladies favours, and vain boasters of counterfeit tokens.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: It is I, it is I, I confess guilty, guilty.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: I will be most human and right courteously languaged in thy correction, and only say, thy vice apparent here has made thee an apparent beggar, and now of a false knave, hath made thee a true fool: Folly to the ship with him, and twice a day let him be ducked at the main yard.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Proceed.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: An Act against slanderers of Cupids liege ladies names, and lewd defamers of their honours.

sp.speaker: Zucc.
sp.p: It is I, it is I, I weep and cry out, I have been a most contumelious offender, my only cry is miserere.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: If your relenting Lady will have pity on you, the fault against our Deity be pardoned.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Madam if ever I have found favour in your eyes, if ever you have thought me a reasonable handsome fellow, as I am sure before I had a beard, you might. O be merciful!

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: Well, upon your apparent repentance, that all modest spectators may witness, I have for a short time only thus feignedly hated you, that you might ever after truly love me, upon these cautions I reaccept you: first you shall vow:

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: I do vow, as heaven bless me, I will do .

sp.speaker: Zo.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Whatever it be, say on I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Zo.
sp.p: You shall vow.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Zo.
sp.p: That you shall never.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: Fain love to my waiting woman or chamber maid.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: Never promise them such a farm to their marriage.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: If she will discover but whom I affect.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: Or if they know none that they will but take a false oath; I do, only to be rid of me .

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: I swear I will not, I will not only not counterfeitly love your women, but I will truly hate them if it be possible, so far from maintaining them that I will beggar them, I will never pick their trunks for letters, search their pockets, ruffle their bosoms, or tear their foul smocks never, never .

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: That if I chance to have a humour to be in a mask, you shall not grow Jealous.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: Or grudge at the expense.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Never, I will eat mine own arms first.

sp.speaker: Zoy.
sp.p: That you shall not, search if my chamber door hinges be oiled to avoid creaking.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: As I am a sensible creature ~~

sp.speaker: Zoy.
sp.p: Nor ever suspect the reason why my bed chamber floor is double matted.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Not as I have blood in me .

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: You shall vow to wear clean lining, and feed wholesomely.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Aye and highly, I will take no more Tobacco, or come to your sheets drunk, or get wenches, I will ever feed on fried frogs, wild snails, and boiled Lamb-stones, I will adore thee more than a mortal, observe and serve you as more than a Mistress, do all duties of a husband, all offices of a man, all services of thy creature, and ever live in thy pleasure, or die in thy service.

sp.speaker: Zo.
sp.p: Then here my quarrel ends, thus cease all strife.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.l: Until they lose, men know not what is a wife,
We sleight and dully view the lamp of heaven,
Because we daily see it, which but bereaved,
And held one little week from darkened eyes,
With greedy wonder, we should all admire,
And proud height of command, puts out loves fire.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: An Act against mummers, false seemers, that abuse ladies with counterfeit faces, courting only by signs;and seeming wise only by silence.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: The penalty.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: To be urged to speak, and then if inward ability answer not outward seeming, to be committed instantly to the ship of fools during great Cupids pleasure. My Lord Granuffo to the bar, speak, speak, is not this law just?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Just sure, for in good truth, or in good sooth, when wise men speak, they still must open their mouth.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: The brazen head has spoken.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Thou art arrested.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Me?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: And judged away.

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.l: Thus silence, can envy looks with hums and haws,
Makes many worshipped, when if tried were daws:
That is the mortality or lenuoy of it lenuoy of it, on.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: An act against privy conspiracies, by which if any with ambitious wisdom, shall hope and strive to outstrip love to cross his words, and make frustrate his sweet pleasures, if such a presumptuous wisdom fall to nothing, and die in laughter, the wizard so transgressing is ipso facto adjudged to offend in most deep treason, to forfeit all his wit at the will of the Lord, and be instantly committed to the ship of fools forever .

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Aye marry sir, O might Edipus riddle me out such a fellow, of all creatures breathing I do hate those things that struggle to seem wise, and yet are indeed very fools, I remember when I was a young man in my fathers days, there were four gallant spirits for resolution, as proper for body, as witty in discourse as any were in Europe, nay Europe had not such, I was one of them, we four did all love one lady, a modest chaste virgin she was, we all enjoyed her, I well remember, and so enjoyed her, that despite the strictest guard was set upon her, we had her at our pleasure, I speak it for her honour and my credit: where shall you find such witty fellows now a days: Alas how easy it is in these weaker times to cross love tricks, ha ha ha alas, alas, I smile to think I must confess with some glory to mine own wisdom, to think how I found out and crossed, and curbed, and jerked, and firked, and in the end made desperate Tiberios hope, Alas good silly youth, that dares to cope with age, and such a beard: I speak it without glory.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: But what yet might your well known wisdom think
If such a one as being most severe,
A most protested opposite to the match
Of two young lovers, who having barred them speech,
All interviews all messages all means
To plot their wished ends, even he himself
Was by their cunning made the go between.
The only messenger the token carrier
Told them the times when they might fitly meet,
Nay, showed the way to one another's bed.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: May one have the sight of such a fellow for nothing;
Doth their breath such an egregious Ass,
Is there such a foolish animal in rerum natura
sp.p: How is it possible such a simplicity can exist? let us not lose our laughing at him for gods sake, let follies sceptre light upon him, and to the ship of fools with him instantly.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Of all these follies I arrest your grace.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Me? ha, me? me varlet? me fool? ha. to the Jail with him: what varlet call me Ass, me?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: What grave Vrbins Duke, dares Follies sceptre touch his prudent shoulders, is he a Coxcomb, no, My Lord is wise, for we all know that Vrbines Duke has eyes.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: God a mercy Fawn, hold fast varlet, hold thee good Fawn, railing reprobate.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: Indeed I must confess, your grace did tell,
And first did intimate your daughters love,
To other wise most cold Tiberio,
After conveyed her private favour to him,
A curious scarf, wherein her needle wrought
Her private favour to him.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: What I do this? ha.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: And last, by her persuasion showed the youth,
The very way and best elected time,
To come unto her chamber.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Thus did I sir?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: This did you sir, but I must confess,
You meant not to do this, but were rankly gulled,
Made a plain natural. This sure sir you did,
And in assurance Prince Tiberio,
Renowned, witted, Dulcimel appeared:
The acts of constant honour cannot fear.

body.stage: Tiberio and Dulcimel aboue are discouered hand in hand.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: Royally wise, and wisely royal father.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: That is sententious now, art Ironia.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: I humbly thank your worthy piety, that through your only means I have obtained so fit, loving and desired a husband.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Death, a discretion, if I should prove a fool now am not I an Ass, think you, ha? I will have them both bound together, and sent to the Duke of Ferrara presently.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: I am sure good Father we are both bound together as fast as the Priest can make us already, I thank you for it kind father, I thank you only for it.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: And as for sending them to the Duke of Ferrara, See my good Lord, Ferraraes over joyed prince meets them in fullest wish.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: By the Lord I am ashamed of myself, that is the plain troth, but I know now wherefore this was: what a slumber have I been in?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: Never grieve or wonder, all things sweetly still.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: There is no folly to protested will.

body.stage: Hercules enters in his one shape.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: What still in wondering, ignorance doth rest,
In private conference, your dear loved breast,
Shall fully take. But now we change our face.
And thus in bold, yet modest phrase we end,
He whose Thalia with swiftest hand hath penned,
This lighter subject, and hath boldly to me,
Fresh bays from Daphnes arm, doth only scorn,
Malicious censures of some envious few,
Who think they lose if others have their due.
But let such Adders hiss, know all the sting,
All the vain some of all those snakes that rings
Mineravas glassful shield can never taint,
Poison or pierce, firm art disdains to faint,
But yet of you that with impartial faces,
With no prepared malice, but with graces,
Of sober knowledge, have surveyed the frame,
Of his sleight scene, if you shall judge his flame,
Distemperately, weak, as faulty much,
In style, in plot, in spirit, lo if such
He deigns in self accusing phrase to crave,
For praise but pardon which he hopes to have ,
Since he protests he ever hath aspired,
To be beloved, rather than admired.
